Factor VIII deficiency is seen in hemophilia A, a blood clotting disorder that leads to serious bleeding (e.g., hemarthrosis, muscular or soft tissue hematomas). Usually only males are affected, as it is primarily an X-linked recessive disease. Treatment includes desmopressin, or in severe cases, substitution of factor VIII. Substitution of EPO would not be effective.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency can impair the coagulation cascade, leading to pathological bleeding. Symptoms include ecchymosis, hematomas, and hemarthroses. Anemia might be seen, but it would not be due to reduced RBC production, so substitution of EPO would not be effective.

C) INCORRECT:

Agranulocytosis is a condition characterized by severe leukopenia. Treatment may involve granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) but not EPO.

D) CORRECT:

Anemia of chronic disease (ACD) occurs in patients with a chronic disease process such as inflammation (e.g., this patient's rheumatoid arthritis), malignancy, infection, or renal failure. ACD is characterized by reduced erythropoietic response to both endogenous and exogenous EPO. However, high doses of EPO can overcome this hyporesponsiveness and are recommended in these patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is an acquired form of a low platelet count secondary to antibody formation against GpIIb/IIIa on platelets. ITP does not perturb the structure or function of WBCs, RBCs, or coagulation factors (i.e., isolated thrombocytopenia). It can be treated with thrombopoietin or thrombopoietin receptor agonists, but EPO would not be effective in treating thrombocytopenia.
questions.hint: Erythropoietin (EPO) stimulates erythroid cell division and proliferation and inhibits erythroid progenitor apoptosis.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-week history of yellowish discoloration of his eyes and skin. He has had generalized fatigue and mild shortness of breath for the past month. Three weeks ago, he was treated for a urinary tract infection with antibiotics. His father underwent a splenectomy during childhood. Examination shows pale conjunctivae and jaundice. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is nontender splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.1 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
89 μm3


Mean corpuscular hemoglobin
32 pg/cell


Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration
37.8% Hb/cell


Leukocyte count
7800/mm3



Platelet count
245,000/mm3



Red cell distribution width

22.8% (N=13%–15%)


Serum



 Bilirubin



 Total

13.8 mg/dL


 Direct

1.9 mg/dL


 Lactate dehydrogenase
450 U/L


Which of the following is the most likely pathophysiology of these findings?

choices.text: Decreased spectrin in the RBC membrane
Decreased synthesis of alpha chains of hemoglobin
Decreased CD55 and CD59 in RBC

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased hemoglobin S can be found in patients with sickle cell anemia (SCA). SCA can also cause jaundice, normocytic anemia, and, in the case of splenic sequestration crisis, splenomegaly. However, splenic sequestration crisis is a medical emergency and patients present very acutely, with a severe drop in hemoglobin, thrombocytopenia, a rapidly enlarging spleen often accompanied by LUQ pain, and potentially hypovolemic shock. This patient does have a drop in hemoglobin, but his splenomegaly is painless, his platelet count is normal, and he presents subacutely, with no symptom progression over several days. Furthermore, because splenectomy is not part of the treatment for SCA, this condition would not sufficiently explain the child's family history (his father underwent splenectomy as a child).

Patients with the homozygote form of SCA can have a mild increase in MCHC (indicating intracellular dehydration). However, this laboratory finding is more specific for another condition.

B) CORRECT:

Decreased spectrin in the RBC membrane is the most common cause of hereditary spherocytosis. Defective RBC membrane proteins (including spectrin and/or ankyrin, among others) lead to continuous loss of the outer lipid bilayer and a decrease in erythrocyte surface area, which creates sphere-shaped erythrocytes (spherocytes) with decreased membrane stability. Spherocyte entrapment in the splenic vasculature causes splenomegaly, and their destruction by splenic macrophages leads to normocytic anemia and jaundice. Laboratory studies show increased MCHC (due to decreased RBC volume from lack of water content), increased RDW (due to anisocytosis), and signs of extravascular hemolysis (including increased LDH and indirect hyperbilirubinemia).

Diagnosis can be confirmed by an eosin-5-maleimide binding test.

C) INCORRECT:

G6PD deficiency can also cause hemolytic anemia, particularly after exposure to oxidative stress (including antibiotics), which is consistent with this patient's splenomegaly, jaundice, hyperbilirubinemia, and increased LDH. However, symptoms usually appear 2–3 days following exposure to oxidative stress (not 2 weeks), and this diagnosis would not explain the elevated MCHC seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased synthesis of alpha chains of hemoglobin results in alpha thalassemia. Presentation of alpha thalassemia is variable depending on clinical severity, but may also cause hemolytic anemia with splenomegaly. However, alpha thalassemia usually presents with a normal RDW and a slightly decreased to low normal MCHC.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased CD55 and CD59 in the RBC membrane is seen in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). PNH can also cause hemolytic anemia but is not associated with an elevated MCHC. Additionally, PNH is usually associated with pancytopenia, and would not be a potential reason for the father's splenectomy.

F) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic microangiopathy may be caused by hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) or thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). These disorders may cause normocytic anemia, jaundice, and hyperbilirubinemia, but are associated with thrombocytopenia (often severe). Additionally, HUS and TTP usually present with fever and hematuria, and could not explain the elevated MCHC seen in this patient. Lastly, gastrointestinal infection (primarily with EHEC O157:H7) would generally precede HUS.

G) INCORRECT:

Pyruvate kinase deficiency can also cause hemolytic anemia with splenomegaly, hyperbilirubinemia, and increased LDH. However, this diagnosis would not explain the elevated MCHC seen in this patient.
questions.hint: The presence of jaundice, normocytic anemia, and splenomegaly in a child with raised MCHC and RDW and laboratory findings of hemolytic anemia (increased LDH and indirect hyperbilirubinemia) is suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. Splenectomy prevents hemolysis and complications (such as gallstone formation and cholecystitis) in this commonly autosomal dominant disease.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of worsening fatigue and dyspnea. She has felt short-of-breath when walking up the stairs to her apartment. Menopause occurred 5 years ago. Her medications are methotrexate and folic acid supplementation. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor, tenderness of bilateral wrists and knees, and ulnar deviation of the fingers. Her hematocrit is 27%, mean corpuscular volume is 84 μm3, and serum ferritin is 475 ng/mL. Which of the following has most likely contributed to the patient's current symptoms?

choices.text: Increased activity of ferroportin-1 in enterocytes
Increased release of iron from macrophages
Increased release of hepcidin by hepatocytes
Increased production of reticulocytes in bone marrow
Increased concentration of transferrin in serum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ferroportin-1 is a transmembrane protein that transports intracellular iron from the enterocytes and macrophages of the reticuloendothelial system into the bloodstream. Increased activity of ferroportin-1 would result in increased serum iron levels. In anemia of chronic disease, the activity of ferroportin-1 is decreased in an attempt by the immune system to make iron unavailable to potential pathogens that require it for replication. This patient with anemia of chronic disease will have decreased rather than increased activity of ferroportin-1.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased release of iron from macrophages occurs in hypoxia and in states of increased erythropoiesis in order to increase the systemic availability of iron for the synthesis of new hemoglobin. In anemia of chronic disease, the innate immune system decreases the release of iron from macrophages in an attempt to make iron unavailable to potential pathogens that use it for replication, so the condition is associated with a decreased rather than an increased release of iron.

C) CORRECT:

Hepcidin is an acute phase reactant that is produced and released by hepatocytes in response to the activation of iron-sensing receptors (e.g., HFE, HJV, and TFR2 proteins) on their surface. Hepcidin synthesis is increased in states of inflammation or high transferrin-bound iron levels (indicating iron overload) and decreased in the setting of hypoxia or increased erythropoiesis. As the body's main regulator of iron metabolism, hepcidin inhibits the absorption of iron from duodenal enterocytes into the bloodstream and iron release from macrophages by binding and degrading ferroportin. In chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis), the trapping of iron results in decreased serum iron levels and increased iron stores, as evidenced by the elevated ferritin in this patient. The change in serum iron levels and iron stores results in iron being unavailable for the synthesis of new hemoglobin, which can lead to anemia of chronic disease. The mainstay of treatment for anemia of chronic disease is management of the underlying disorder.
Image Description:

Intraluminal ferric iron (i.e., dietary iron or heme) is converted to ferrous iron (Fe2+) by ascorbate ferrireductase and transported into the enterocyte via the DMT-1 transporter. Fe2+ is then either stored as ferritin or transported to the circulation (shaded red area) to contribute towards hematopoiesis. This circulating Fe2+ from dietary or other sources (i.e., apoferritin stores in the liver, breakdown of hemoglobin) is then recycled to form new hemoglobin molecules within the medullary and extramedullary sites of hematopoiesis or exported and stored as ferritin within the hepatocytes. Iron metabolism is controlled by the hepcidin protein, which is produced in response to increased levels of plasma iron, inflammation, or the HFE protein, and acts to inhibit iron uptake into the circulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased production of reticulocytes occurs in anemia with effective compensatory erythropoiesis (e.g., hemolytic anemia, bleeding). Anemia of chronic disease is a hypoproliferative condition caused by a relative decrease in serum erythropoietin, reduced bone marrow response to erythropoietin, and a decrease in the systemic availability of iron. Therefore, this patient's production of reticulocytes will be decreased, not increased.

E) INCORRECT:

Transferrin is an iron-transport protein. An increased serum concentration of transferrin indicates high iron-binding capacity, which would be seen in conditions such as iron deficiency and pregnancy. Anemia of chronic disease is associated with low iron-binding capacity because the condition is a result of impaired iron utilization and not iron deficiency. Therefore, the concentration of serum transferrin in this patient would be normal or decreased, not increased.
questions.hint: This patient's worsening fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, conjunctival pallor, rheumatoid arthritis, and normocytic anemia with elevated ferritin are indicative of anemia of chronic disease.

questions.text: A previously healthy 39-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of fatigue and red-colored urine. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows pallor and jaundice. His platelet count is 90,000/mm3 and creatinine concentration is 1.0 mg/dL. A direct Coombs test is negative. Flow cytometry shows erythrocytes deficient in CD55 and CD59 surface antigens. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Seizures are a common feature of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), which can manifest with anemia, jaundice, and red urine due to microangiopathic (intravascular) hemolysis. A low platelet count and negative Coombs test are also seen in TTP. However, other characteristic features of TTP, such as fever and impaired renal function, are absent in this patient. Furthermore, patients with TTP show decreased ADAMTS13 activity rather than CD55/59-negative erythrocytes. Seizures are not a typical feature of PNH, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiolucency is characteristic of cholesterol gallstones, which are associated with obesity, advanced age, Crohn disease, and estrogen therapy. Brown pigment gallstones caused by biliary tract infections also display radiolucency. Patients with hemolytic anemia such as PNH, however, are at an increased risk of developing calcium bilirubinate gallstones, which are radioopaque, black pigment stones.

C) INCORRECT:

Acrocyanosis is a common feature of cold agglutinin disease, not PNH. Autoimmune hemolytic anemias (AIHA) such as cold agglutinin disease can also manifest with signs of intravascular hemolysis (e.g., anemia, jaundice, red urine), which are seen in this patient. However, in AIHA, the Coombs test is positive, reflecting the presence of anti-RBC autoantibodies.

D) CORRECT:

Venous thrombosis is the leading cause of mortality in PNH. Thrombosis associated with PNH occurs in atypical locations, such as hepatic veins (Budd-Chiari syndrome), portal veins, and cerebral veins (headache, stroke). The mechanism for thrombosis is still largely unknown. Patients with PNH are also at increased risk of developing aplastic anemia and acute leukemia (especially AML). Hemolysis in PNH is caused by an acquired genetic defect in the glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor that attaches CD55 and CD59 proteins to the membrane. CD55 and CD59 protect erythrocytes from complement-mediated hemolysis. Eculizumab, an anti-C5 antibody, is used to treat PNH. It targets a key component of complement-mediated hemolysis, reducing intravascular hemolysis.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with hepatitis C infection or hereditary hemochromatosis (HH) are at an increased risk for hepatocellular carcinoma. Liver failure caused by these conditions also manifests with fatigue and jaundice, which are seen in this patient. While hepatitis C infection may also involve thrombocytopenia (due to ITP) and red urine (due to mixed cryoglobulinemia or AIHA), the hemolytic anemia associated with it would result in a positive Coombs test. HH, on the other hand, can be ruled out in this patient based on the fact that HH does not result in red urine. Also, HH typically manifests in patients older than 40 years of age with hepatomegaly, skin hyperpigmentation, arthralgia and/or diabetes mellitus, which are not reported here.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with PNH are at increased risk of developing acute leukemias (especially acute myeloid leukemia), not chronic leukemias such as CLL. Risk factors for CLL include advanced age (> 50 years) and exposure to Agent Orange.
questions.hint: Deficiency of CD55 and CD59 surface antigens indicates paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), which manifests with features of intravascular hemolysis (e.g., jaundice, red urine due to hemoglobinuria) and pancytopenia (due to bone marrow failure).

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by police because of confusion and agitation. Her medical record indicates that she has peptic ulcer disease that is treated with omeprazole. The patient's brother arrives shortly after. He reports that she drinks around 17 oz. of vodka daily. Neurological examination shows horizontal nystagmus. Her gait is wide-based with small steps. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.1 g/dL. A peripheral blood smear mean shows hypersegmented neutrophils. Homocysteine levels are elevated. Methylmalonic acid levels are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely direct cause of this patient's anemia?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Alcohol use disorder increases the risk of developing folate deficiency. Folate deficiency results in megaloblastic anemia and is associated with increased MCV, hypersegmented neutrophils, increased homocysteine levels, and normal methylmalonic acid levels. The ataxia, nystagmus, and confusion in this patient can be explained by acute intoxication, alcohol-induced cerebellar atrophy, and/or Wernicke encephalopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin E deficiency can result in nystagmus and ataxia (due to spinocerebellar degeneration) as well as anemia, all of which are seen here. Confusion may also occur in longterm deficiency. However, vitamin E deficiency usually manifests with hemolytic anemia, and this patient has no signs of hemolysis (e.g., jaundice, dark urine). In addition, it would not cause hypersegmented neutrophils. Vitamin E deficiency is typically associated with disorders of fat absorption (e.g., chronic pancreatitis, cholestatic disease, ileal resection, celiac disease), which this patient does not have.

C) INCORRECT:

Alcohol itself can cause macrocytic anemia due to decreased production and increased destruction of RBCs, even without concurrent nutritional deficiencies. Chronic alcohol abuse explains the neurological findings seen in this patient (Wernicke encephalopathy secondary to thiamine deficiency). However, alcoholism itself does not result in elevated levels of homocysteine, indicating a different cause of her anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency is a common complication of peptic ulcer disease (e.g., as a result of chronic occult GI bleeding). It commonly results in microcytic anemia with a low MCV. Iron deficiency would not cause the elevated homocysteine levels seen in this patient, making another diagnosis more likely.

Hypersegmented neutrophils may also occur in conjunction with iron deficiency anemia, the cause of which is unknown.

E) INCORRECT:

Alcohol use and the chronic use of acid-reducing agents (e.g., cimetidine, omeprazole) are risk factors for vitamin B12 deficiency. Patients with vitamin B12 deficiency may present with ataxia (due to subacute combined degeneration and/or peripheral neuropathy), hypersegmented neutrophils, and macrocytic anemia, which this patient has. However, levels of both homocysteine and methylmalonic acid would be increased in vitamin B12 deficiency.

F) INCORRECT:

Chronic alcohol use is a risk factor for thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Patients with a thiamine deficiency may present with confusion, horizontal nystagmus, and ataxia as a result of Wernicke encephalopathy. However, thiamine deficiency does not typically cause anemia.

Thiamine-responsive megaloblastic anemia is a rare genetic disease that manifests with macrocytic anemia and is responsive to treatment with thiamine. However, the onset of this disorder is during childhood or adolescence, and it involves other clinical findings such as type 1 diabetes mellitus and sensorineural hearing loss.
questions.hint: Mean corpuscular volume would be elevated in this patient.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old African American woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of worsening fatigue that started 1 year ago. Physical examination shows mild jaundice and splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.4 g/dL


Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration
43% Hb/cell


Platelet count
220,000/mm3



Reticulocyte count
7%


A peripheral blood smear shows target cells and erythrocytes with hemoglobin crystals. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Replacement of glutamate by valine in beta-globin chain
Decreased conversion of oxidized glutathione into its reduced form
Replacement of glutamate by lysine in beta-globin chain
Reduced production of beta-globin due to a mutation in the HbB gene
Acquired mutation of membrane-bound glycosylphosphatidylinositol anchor
Inherited defects in spectrin and ankyrin RBC membrane proteins

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sickle cell disease is caused by the replacement of glutamate by valine in the β-globin chain of hemoglobin, resulting in HbS. This patient's peripheral blood smear does not show sickle cells, which makes the diagnosis of sickle cell anemia unlikely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Numerous crescent-shaped erythrocytes, known as “sickle cells,” can be seen (examples indicated by blue overlay; two normal erythrocytes are indicated by arrowheads for comparison). Erythrocytes with a red center and a white contouring ring, known as “target cells” (yellow overlay; cf. illustration) are visible at the bottom of the image.

Sickle cells are pathognomonic of sickle-cell disease. Target cells can be found in sickle-cell disease and other hemoglobinopathies.

B) INCORRECT:

In glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD deficiency), decreased enzymatic conversion of oxidized glutathione to its reduced form can cause hemolytic anemia. G6PD deficiency is the most common RBC enzyme deficiency and symptoms are triggered by oxidant stress (e.g., consumption of fava beans, infection, antimalarial medication). However, this patient does not have a history of recurrent hemolytic crises in response to expected triggers, nor does her peripheral blood smear show characteristic signs of G6PD deficiency such as Heinz bodies and bite cells.
Image Description:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

C) CORRECT:

Hemoglobin C disease is a congenital hemoglobinopathy that is characterized by mild hemolytic anemia (↓ hemoglobin, reticulocyte count >2%) with red blood cell dehydration (↑ MCHC) and is caused by the replacement of glutamate by lysine in the β-globin chain of hemoglobin. Peripheral blood smear of homozygotes will classically show hemoglobin crystals in the RBCs (due to less soluble, precipitated hemoglobin C), as well as numerous target cells. Characteristic symptoms include signs of hemolytic anemia such as jaundice, splenomegaly, and fatigue.

D) INCORRECT:

Reduced production of β-globin due to a mutation in the β-globin gene is seen in β-thalassemia, which causes a microcytic, hypochromic anemia. β-thalassemia minor is usually asymptomatic, but β-thalassemia major typically presents with severe hemolytic anemia. However, the mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) would be reduced rather than elevated. Furthermore, peripheral blood smear would show target cells and teardrop cells (dacrocytes), but hemoglobin crystals would not be found.

E) INCORRECT:

Acquired mutation of the membrane-bound glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor is seen in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), in which the protective effect of the GPI anchor is lost, leading to RBC destruction and hemolysis. However, platelet count is typically reduced in patients with PNH, which is not seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

Inherited defects in RBC membrane proteins (such as spectrin or ankyrin) are seen in hereditary spherocytosis, which can also present with signs of hemolytic anemia (e.g., ↓ hemoglobin, ↑ reticulocytes, jaundice, splenomegaly, and fatigue). In patients with hereditary spherocytosis, however, peripheral blood smear characteristically shows spherocytes, making this diagnosis unlikely in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Multiple spherocytes can be seen (red circles), which have a typical round (rather than biconcave) shape and no central pallor. The erythrocytes vary significantly in size, which is consistent with anisocytosis (red arrows). On electron microscopy (overlay box with drawings based on EM appearance), the spherical shape of spherocytes (1) and normal biconcave erythrocytes (2) can be seen.
questions.hint: The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings, including the hemoglobin crystals on peripheral blood smear, suggest hemolytic anemia caused by hemoglobin C disease.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath. Physical examination shows generalized pallor. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
5.8 g/dL


Hematocrit
17%


Mean corpuscular volume
86 μm3



Leukocyte count
6200/mm3 with a normal differential


Platelet count
240,000/mm3



A bone marrow aspirate shows an absence of erythroid precursor cells. This patient’s condition is most likely associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cold agglutinins can cause autoimmune hemolytic anemia, which manifests with normocytic anemia. However, unlike this patient, erythroid precursor cells would be present.

B) INCORRECT:

FANCA mutation is associated with Fanconi anemia, which typically manifests in childhood with pancytopenia (rather than pure red cell aplasia), developmental delay, skeletal, and organ abnormalities (e.g., short stature, thumb and forearm malformations, café-au-lait spots, and microcephaly). Furthermore, almost 50% of patients develop acute myeloid leukemia or myelodysplastic syndrome in early adulthood.

C) INCORRECT:

HbF persistence with pure red cell aplasia is typically found in Diamond-Blackfan anemia. Unlike this patient, Diamond-Blackfan anemia typically manifests in childhood with macrocytic, nonmegaloblastic anemia, and congenital malformations (e.g., short stature, webbed neck, low set ears, small jaw, and triphalangeal thumbs).
Image Description:

X-ray right and left thumb (PA view)

A small triangular bone (delta phalanx, or longitudinal epiphyseal bracket; red overlay) is present between the proximal and distal phalanx of each thumb. There is ulnar deviation of the distal thumbs.

A delta phalanx can appear as an isolated finding or as part of a wide variety of congenital syndromes and dysplasias.

D) CORRECT:

PRCA in adults is most often idiopathic but can be associated with other conditions. Thymoma, a thymic tumor, may cause a paraneoplastic syndrome that manifests with PRCA. Although the pathophysiology of PRCA is not well understood, it is thought to be related to abnormal T-cell function and IgG antibodies that target erythroblasts and erythropoietin. PRCA may also be associated with myelodysplastic syndrome, drugs (e.g., phenytoin, chloramphenicol), and parvovirus B19 infection.

Treatment of pure red cell aplasia in this patient would include a thymectomy, RBC transfusions, and additional medications such as corticosteroids, cyclosporine, or cyclophosphamide if surgery alone does not lead to remission of the aplasia.
Image Description:

CT chest (with contrast; mediastinal window; axial plane)

A heterogeneous anterior mediastinal mass (green overlay) with an irregular border (example indicated by green arrowheads) contains a central rim-enhancing (red overlay) hypodense area of cystic or necrotic change (green hatched overlay).

Anterior mediastinal tumors commonly derive from the thymus gland, fat, or lymph nodes. Noninvasive thymomas are often well-defined masses with homogeneous enhancement. Invasive thymomas are more likely to be irregular or lobulated and to contain hypodense areas and calcification. The imaging characteristics of thymic carcinomas and neuroendocrine tumors can overlap with those of high-grade thymomas. Evidence of pleural or pericardial involvement, pleural effusion, or distant metastases is more suggestive of thymic carcinoma or a neuroendocrine tumor rather than thymoma.

AA: ascending aorta; DA: descending aorta; LPA: left pulmonary artery; PT: pulmonary trunk; RPA: right pulmonary artery; SVC: superior vena cava

E) INCORRECT:

Lead poisoning typically manifests with microcytic, hypochromic anemia as well as abdominal pain (lead colic), Burton line, and/or paralysis of the radial or peroneal nerve (wrist drop/foot drop). This patient has a normal MCV and lacks the other typical features of lead poisoning.
Image Description:

The gums and teeth of a 7-year-old boy

A purplish-blue line (Burton line; green overlay) is visible at the margin of the gums.

A Burton line is typically seen in patients with chronic lead poisoning.
questions.hint: Anemia with an absence of RBC precursors but normal production of platelets and WBCs indicates pure red cell aplasia (PRCA).

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of generalized weakness and difficulty walking for the past month. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 6.6 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 70 μm3, platelet count of 150,000/mm3, and serum total bilirubin concentration of 2 mg/dl. An MRI of the spine shows low signal intensity in all vertebral bodies and a small epidural mass compressing the spinal canal at the level of L1. A CT scan of the head shows osteopenia with widening of the diploic spaces in the skull. A biopsy of the epidural mass shows erythroid colonies with an abundance of megakaryocytes and myeloid cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hereditary spherocytosis can cause anemia and hyperbilirubinemia as a result of hemolysis. However, in hereditary spherocytosis, extramedullary hematopoiesis is rare, and patients usually develop normocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

G6PD deficiency can cause anemia and hyperbilirubinemia as a result of hemolysis, but only after exposure to significant oxidative stress (e.g., infection, consumption of fava beans). Furthermore, in G6PD deficiency, extramedullary hematopoiesis is rare, and patients usually develop normocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia.
Image Description:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

C) INCORRECT:

Aplastic anemia manifests with pancytopenia and normocytic anemia, whereas this patient presents with a normal platelet count and microcytic anemia. Moreover, aplastic anemia would not be associated with hyperbilirubinemia and it does not lead to extramedullary hematopoiesis.

D) INCORRECT:

Lead poisoning can cause microcytic anemia as well as mild hyperbilirubinemia due to hemolysis. However, this patient does not have the typical clinical manifestations of lead poisoning (e.g., intestinal colic, anorexia, constipation, encephalopathy). Furthermore, lead poisoning does not cause extramedullary hematopoiesis.

E) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma (MM) can cause anemia and masses in the soft tissue (extramedullary plasmacytoma) or bone. However, the anemia associated with MM is normocytic or macrocytic, not microcytic, and a biopsy of such a mass would show ≥ 10% clonal plasma cells, not erythroid colonies. Moreover, imaging of the skull would reveal focal lytic lesions with a punched-out appearance, not widening of the diploic spaces. Finally, multiple myeloma is typically diagnosed in adults; it is extremely rare in children.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myeloma

Multiple punched-out lytic lesions (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible. This appearance is termed “raindrop sign” from the resemblance of these lesions to raindrops splashing upon hitting a surface.

An expanded differential of lucent skull lesions includes osteoporosis of aging, hyperparathyroidism, metastatic disease, anemias (e.g., sickle cell and thalassemia), and the lytic phase of Paget disease.

F) CORRECT:

In patients with beta thalassemia, defective hemoglobin chain synthesis results in ineffective hematopoiesis and subsequent chronic anemia. In a state of severe chronic anemia, extramedullary hematopoiesis often occurs as a compensatory mechanism. Extramedullary hematopoiesis most commonly involves the paravertebral areas, as seen in this patient, followed by the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes.

While extramedullary hematopoiesis in the spleen and liver is physiological during fetal development, it is always pathological after birth.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view) of a child with beta thalassemia

Expansion of the diploic space with thickening of the trabeculae (example indicated by green overlay) is the result of extramedullary hematopoiesis. The hair-on-end appearance (examples indicated by red lines) produced can also be seen in other chronic hemolytic anemias.
questions.hint: The presence of erythroid colonies in the epidural space on biopsy and widening of the diploic spaces in the skull on imaging indicate extramedullary hematopoiesis.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fatigue. He reports that during this time he has had occasional palpitations and shortness of breath. He has sickle cell disease. Current medications include hydroxyurea and folic acid. He appears fatigued. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. Cardiac examination shows a midsystolic ejection murmur. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
6.4 g/dl


Leukocyte count
6,000/mm3



Platelet count
168,000/mm3



Mean corpuscular volume
84 μm3



Reticulocyte count
0.1%


Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This boy's anemia is most likely due to an infection with parvovirus B19, which is commonly associated with a transient cessation of erythropoiesis in patients with SCD. In otherwise healthy individuals, red blood cells (RBCs) have a consistent lifespan in balance with new RBC production, so that clinically relevant drops in hemoglobin are very rare. However, patients with underlying hemolytic anemias, such as SCD and hereditary spherocytosis, have RBCs with a decreased lifespan. In these patients, the transient cessation of erythropoiesis may result in an acute drop in Hb with associated reticulocytopenia (i.e., transient aplastic crisis). TAC is usually self-limited and reticulocyte production recurs within a few days.

B) INCORRECT:

Medication-induced hemolysis is commonly seen in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency. Drugs that may lead to hemolysis include antimalarial drugs (e.g., chloroquine, primaquine), sulfa drugs (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), nitrofurantoin, isoniazid, dapsone, NSAIDs, ciprofloxacin, and chloramphenicol. Patients often present with an acute drop in hemoglobin. However, hemolytic anemia is usually associated with an increased reticulocyte count. Moreover, this patient has a history of SCD and did not receive any of the previously mentioned medications.
Image Description:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

C) INCORRECT:

A defect in erythrocyte membrane proteins (e.g., ankyrin, spectrin) is seen in patients with hereditary spherocytosis. Like SCD, hereditary spherocytosis may also manifest with aplastic crisis, as seen here. However, hereditary spherocytosis is not known to cause aplastic crisis in patients with SCD.

SCD is associated with abnormal hemoglobin rather than dysfunctional erythrocyte membrane proteins.

D) INCORRECT:

Splenic vaso-occlusion is the underlying cause of splenic sequestration crisis, which usually presents with acute-onset anemia, as seen here. However, unlike in this boy, anemia in splenic sequestration crisis is associated with an increased reticulocyte count. Additionally, patients characteristically have acute left upper quadrant pain (due to rapid enlargement of the spleen) and signs of intravascular volume depletion (e.g., severe hypotension) due to blood being trapped in the spleen. Lastly, splenic sequestration crisis primarily affects infants and young children; older children and adults with SCD often have a nonfunctional, atrophic spleen because of years of damage from sickled cells.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic crisis is the underlying cause of hyperhemolysis. Patients with hyperhemolysis present with acute-onset anemia, as seen here. However, they do not have bone marrow suppression and their reticulocyte count is increased in order to compensate for the decreased hemoglobin.
questions.hint: This patient has sickle cell disease (SCD) and presents with severe symptomatic anemia (evident from his palpitations, shortness of breath, tachycardia, and ejection murmur) and a low reticulocyte count, which suggests impaired erythropoiesis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of fatigue and weakness. Examination shows marked pallor of the conjunctivae. The spleen tip is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.5 g/dL, serum lactate dehydrogenase concentration is 750 IU/L, and her serum haptoglobin is undetectable. A peripheral blood smear shows multiple spherocytes. When anti-IgG antibodies are added to a sample of the patient's blood, there is clumping of the red blood cells. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), which is caused by an acquired mutation in the PIGA gene that makes erythrocytes susceptible to destruction by complement, is a rare cause of both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis. Patients with PNH can present with features of hemolytic anemia and splenomegaly (due to venous thrombosis), as this patient does. However, this patient lacks other signs and symptoms of PNH such as red urine (due to hemoglobinuria) or jaundice. Moreover, the anemia in PNH is Coombs-negative and the peripheral blood smear would not show spherocytes.

B) INCORRECT:

A hereditary defect in erythrocyte spectrin is the underlying cause of hereditary spherocytosis (HS). The clinical presentation of HS is variable, but the majority of affected patients develop symptoms of anemia, jaundice, and/or splenomegaly during infancy or childhood. While HS could explain the features of hemolytic anemia and the spherocytosis on blood smear that this patient has, a positive Coombs test would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

A bicuspid aortic valve is a risk factor for early aortic stenosis. Aortic stenosis can cause mechanical destruction of the RBCs, resulting in macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia. A peripheral blood smear in macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia would show schistocytes, not spherocytes as seen here. Moreover, macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia would not explain this patient's splenomegaly or the positive Coombs test.

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) can lead to splenomegaly and cold agglutinin syndrome (CAS). Patients with cold agglutinin disease can present with features of hemolytic anemia and mild spherocytosis. However, this patient does not have other typical findings of patients with CAS such as acrocyanosis or livedo reticularis. Moreover, Coombs test in CAS would show IgM cold-antibodies and/or complement fragments on the surface of erythrocytes, not IgG antibodies as seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Infection with Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of cold agglutinin syndrome (CAS). Patients with cold agglutinin disease can present with features of hemolytic anemia and mild spherocytosis. However, this patient does not have other typical findings of patients with CAS such as acrocyanosis or livedo reticularis. Moreover, Coombs test in CAS would show IgM cold-antibodies and/or complement fragments on the surface of RBCs, not IgG antibodies as seen here.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation and laboratory findings are consistent with warm agglutinin disease, a type of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). The presence of warm-active IgG antibodies against erythrocytes results in hemolytic anemia, spherocytosis, splenomegaly (due to the removal of antibody-tagged erythrocytes by the splenic reticuloendothelial system). The most common predisposing factors for warm agglutinin disease include autoimmune disorders (e.g., SLE), lymphomas (e.g., CLL), viral infections in children (e.g., HIV), and use of certain drugs (e.g., α-methyldopa).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Multiple spherocytes can be seen (red circles), which have a typical round (rather than biconcave) shape and no central pallor. The erythrocytes vary significantly in size, which is consistent with anisocytosis (red arrows). On electron microscopy (overlay box with drawings based on EM appearance), the spherical shape of spherocytes (1) and normal biconcave erythrocytes (2) can be seen.
questions.hint: The patient presents with features of anemia (fatigue, pallor, decreased hemoglobin concentration) and hemolysis (increased LDH, undetectable haptoglobin). The positive direct Coombs test (agglutination of RBCs in response to anti-IgG) and spherocytes on peripheral blood smear are suggestive of autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

questions.text:
A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he has become increasingly pale over the past several months. He has otherwise been healthy. Apart from his maternal grandfather, who had a blood disorder and required frequent blood transfusions since birth, the rest of his family, including his parents and older sister, are healthy. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
7.7 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
64.8 μm3



Serum



Iron
187 μg/dL


Ferritin
306 ng/mL


A bone marrow aspirate shows numerous ringed sideroblasts. The patient is most likely deficient in an enzyme responsible for which of the following reactions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This reaction is catalyzed by δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALA dehydratase). A genetic deficiency of this enzyme leads to an extremely rare form of acute intermittent porphyria. ALA dehydratase porphyria manifests with abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric symptoms. Anemia, ringed sideroblasts, and iron overload would not be expected. More commonly, ALA dehydratase dysfunction is a result of lead poisoning. Lead poisoning can cause sideroblastic anemia, which is seen here. However, further symptoms such as neurological dysfunction (e.g., foot drop, encephalopathy) and a Burton line would also be expected. This patient's family history suggests X-linked hereditary sideroblastic anemia, which is associated with a deficiency of a different enzyme.

B) CORRECT:

This reaction, which is the first and rate-limiting step of heme synthesis, is catalyzed by δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase. A deficiency of this enzyme leads to insufficient heme production, which results in iron overload and perinuclear accumulation of iron-loaded mitochondria (i.e., ringed sideroblasts). A peripheral blood smear would show basophilic stippling. Sideroblastic anemia can be hereditary, as in this case, but can also be acquired as a result of heavy alcohol consumption, vitamin B6 deficiency, lead poisoning, copper deficiency, or myelodysplastic syndromes.
Image Description:

Overview of heme synthesis and its key enzymes as well as the molecular causes of several diseases that interfere with heme synthesis.

C) INCORRECT:

This reaction is catalyzed by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD), which is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway. G6PD deficiency is also an X-linked recessive disorder that manifests with anemia. However, anemia typically only occurs in hemolytic crises triggered by infections or certain medications, and symptoms would include acute abdominal pain and jaundice. Ringed sideroblasts are not seen in this disorder.
Image Description:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

D) INCORRECT:

This reaction is catalyzed by porphobilinogen deaminase. A genetic deficiency of this enzyme is seen in acute intermittent porphyria, which typically manifests in adults with abdominal pain, polyneuropathy, port-wine colored urine, and psychiatric symptoms. Anemia, ringed sideroblasts, and iron overload are not seen in this disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

This reaction is catalyzed by ferrochelatase. A genetic deficiency of this enzyme leads to erythropoietic protoporphyria, which can manifest with sideroblastic anemia. However, the typical presentation includes a tender, nonblistering, photosensitive rash appearing in early childhood. More commonly, ferrochelatase dysfunction is a result of lead poisoning. Lead poisoning can also cause sideroblastic anemia. However, further symptoms such as neurological dysfunction (e.g., foot drop, encephalopathy) and a Burton line would also be expected. This patient's family history suggests X-linked hereditary sideroblastic anemia, which is associated with a deficiency of a different enzyme.

F) INCORRECT:

This reaction is catalyzed by uroporphyrinogen III decarboxylase. A deficiency of this enzyme is seen in familial porphyria cutanea tarda, which is an autosomal dominant condition with incomplete penetrance. Although high iron levels increase susceptibility to this disease, it typically manifests in adults with photosensitivity and painful skin blistering, which are not seen here. Furthermore, neither anemia nor ringed sideroblasts are seen in this disorder.
questions.hint: This patient has microcytic anemia, serum studies indicating iron overload, and ringed sideroblasts on bone marrow aspirate. These features and the inheritance pattern (maternal grandfather affected) are consistent with X-linked sideroblastic anemia.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painless, progressively enlarging swelling in his neck over the past 6 months. He also reports feeling more tired than usual. He has a history of hypertension treated with ramipril. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows nontender, rubber lymphadenopathy in the right supraclavicular region. The abdomen is soft; the liver edge and spleen tip are not palpable. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
84 μm3


Red cell distribution width

14% (N = 13–15)



Reticulocyte count
0.3%


Leukocyte count
10,500/mm3 with a normal differential


Platelet count
210,000/mm3



Serum



Total bilirubin
0.3 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is negative. A peripheral blood smear shows no abnormalities. Further workup establishes a diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma. A bone marrow biopsy shows mildly increased iron stores within macrophages but no evidence of tumor infiltration. This patient is most likely to have which of the following sets of laboratory findings?



Total iron binding capacity
Transferrin saturation
Serum soluble transferrin receptor
Serum ferritin
Serum iron



A
↓
↓
normal
↑
↓


B
↑
↓
↑
↓
↓


C
↑
↓
normal
normal
normal


D
↓
↑
↓
↑
↑
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anemia of chronic disease (ACD) is caused by decreased erythropoiesis despite adequate iron stores. Chronic disease causes chronic inflammation with a consequent increase in hepcidin and cytokines (e.g., IL-6). These transmitters increase intracellular iron retention in macrophages and decrease intestinal iron absorption. As a result, serum iron levels and, consequently, transferrin saturation decrease. Transferrin, which is a negative inflammatory marker, can also be reduced in inflammation, indicated by a low total iron-binding capacity. Furthermore, the involved cytokines increase the transcription of acute phase reactant ferritin, resulting in high serum ferritin levels. Finally, these cytokines also inhibit erythropoiesis in the bone marrow, resulting in a low reticulocyte count. Expression of the transferrin receptor (TfR) is not affected in ACD and soluble TfR concentration remains normal. Later phase ACD may be accompanied by iron deficiency and manifest with microcytic anemia. Since ACD is a diagnosis of exclusion, causes of anemia other than ACD need to be ruled out by appropriate investigations.

B) INCORRECT:

These findings indicate iron deficiency anemia, which can also manifest with normocytic anemia, especially in the early stages, and a low reticulocyte count due to decreased erythropoiesis. However, in iron deficiency anemia, iron stores in the bone marrow are typically decreased and RDW is increased.

C) INCORRECT:

These findings can be seen in pregnant women. Pregnancy leads to dilutional, normocytic anemia and increased transferrin production, resulting in an increased total iron binding capacity along with decreased transferrin saturation and normal ferritin and serum iron levels. Soluble transferrin receptor concentration increases slightly in the second and third trimester but still remains within the reference range in normal pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

These findings suggest iron overload, which increases iron storage in bone marrow macrophages, similar to what is seen here. The constellation of iron overload with anemia occurs in sideroblastic anemia and secondary hemochromatosis (e.g., due to thalassemia or transfusion-dependent hemolytic anemia). Sideroblastic anemia typically causes microcytic anemia, basophilic stippling of erythrocytes on a peripheral blood smear, and an increased RDW, none of which are seen here. Furthermore, this patient does not have a history of thalassemia or repeated transfusions to suggest secondary hemochromatosis.
questions.hint: This patient's findings are consistent with early-stage Hodgkin lymphoma (i.e., without bone marrow infiltration). In a patient with malignancy, normocytic anemia and normal red cell distribution width (RDW) suggest anemia of chronic disease.

Abdominal: spleen tip palpated 4 cm below the left costal margin; liver cannot be palpated
Neurologic: lower back pain; 3/5 bilateral lower extremity weakness; diminished sensation below the level of L1; bilateral lower limb hyperreflexia

Diagnostic Studies


Blood

skull x-ray: shown
MRI of the spine: low signal intensity in all vertebral bodies; small epidural mass compressing the spinal canal at the level of L1
histopathology of a biopsy sample from the epidural mass: erythroid colonies with an abundance of megakaryocytes and myeloid cells



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Microcytic hypochromic anemia, indirect hyperbilirubinemia due to peripheral hemolysis, a Mentzer index < 13, and extramedullary hematopoiesis indicate beta thalassemia. Beta thalassemia is caused by defective hemoglobin chain synthesis, which leads to ineffective hematopoiesis and subsequent chronic anemia. Extramedullary hematopoiesis often occurs as a compensatory mechanism in patients with chronic anemia and commonly involves the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes and can also affect the bones (e.g., skull) and paravertebral areas, causing spinal cord compression, which can lead to lower extremity weakness, hyperreflexia, and decreased sensation below the level of compression. Extramedullary hematopoiesis in the spleen and liver is physiological during fetal development but is always pathological after birth.

B) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma (MM) can cause anemia and masses in the soft tissue (extramedullary plasmacytoma) or bone. However, MM is associated with normocytic or macrocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia, and histopathology of a biopsy sample would show ≥ 10% clonal plasma cells rather than erythroid colonies. Moreover, imaging of the skull would reveal focal lytic lesions with a punched-out appearance, not widening of the diploic spaces. Also, MM is extremely rare in children.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myeloma

Multiple punched-out lytic lesions (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible. This appearance is termed “raindrop sign” from the resemblance of these lesions to raindrops splashing upon hitting a surface.

An expanded differential of lucent skull lesions includes osteoporosis of aging, hyperparathyroidism, metastatic disease, anemias (e.g., sickle cell and thalassemia), and the lytic phase of Paget disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Lead poisoning can cause microcytic anemia and mild hyperbilirubinemia as a result of hemolysis. However, typical features such as intestinal colic, anorexia, constipation, and encephalopathy would also be expected. Furthermore, lead poisoning does not cause extramedullary hematopoiesis.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) can develop secondary to a myelodysplastic syndrome and can manifest with extramedullary hematopoiesis and splenomegaly. However, AML also usually manifests with pancytopenia as a result of uncontrolled proliferation of abnormal myeloid cells in the bone marrow. Also, AML is extremely rare in children.

E) INCORRECT:

Aplastic anemia manifests with pancytopenia including normocytic anemia, whereas this patient has a normal platelet and WBC count and microcytic anemia. Moreover, aplastic anemia does not result in hyperbilirubinemia or extramedullary hematopoiesis.

F) INCORRECT:

Langerhans cell histiocytosis can cause splenomegaly and bone marrow infiltration. However, extramedullary hematopoiesis is rare in Langerhans cell histiocytosis, and histopathology of a biopsy sample would typically reveal polygonal cells with coffee bean-shaped nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm (i.e., Langerhans cell proliferation) rather than erythroid colonies with an abundance of megakaryocytes and myeloid cells.
questions.hint: Splenomegaly, biopsy-confirmed erythroid colonies in the epidural space, and widening of the diploic spaces in the skull on x-ray indicate extramedullary hematopoiesis.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with fatigue. He reports that for the past two years, he has taken several tablets of zinc daily to prevent colds.
His laboratory results are as follows:

7.5

Platelet count (per mm3)
90,000
150,000–350,000



Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
105
80–100


Deficiency of which one of the following dietary components is this patient most likely to have?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Manganese deficiency is not typically associated with anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, which is characterized by malaise, lethargy, myalgias, bruising, petechiae, gum disease, loosening of the teeth, and poor wound healing, but not anemia.

C) CORRECT:

Pancytopenia with macrocytic anemia suggests myelodysplastic syndrome, especially in older patients. Before a diagnosis of myelodysplastic syndrome is made, however, it is important to rule out reversible causes of bone-marrow dysfunction, including deficiencies in copper, vitamin B12, and folic acid.

Etiologies of copper deficiency include excessive zinc intake, malabsorptive diseases, prior bowel resection, and bariatric surgery or gastrectomy.

Key learning point: The mineral deficiency that can manifest with features of myelodysplastic syndrome is copper deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin A deficiency causes night blindness but is not associated with anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency would cause microcytosis, not macrocytosis, and would not cause pancytopenia.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman with a long-standing history of rheumatoid arthritis and fatigue is found to be anemic. She takes hydroxychloroquine and intermittent glucocorticoids to control her rheumatoid arthritis. There have been no recent changes in these or her other medications, which include ibuprofen, acetaminophen, and omeprazole.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.2
12.0–16.0


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
90
80–100


C-reactive protein (mg/liter)
5.00
0.08–3.10



Ferritin (ng/mL)
950
30–300



Iron (μg/dL)
40
30–160



Total iron-binding capacity (μg/dL)
190
250–370


Reticulocyte count (% red cells)
1.0
0.5–2.5


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.8

What is the most likely cause of this patient’s anemia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with alpha-thalassemia, iron studies are abnormal and show an elevated serum iron level (due to chronic transfusions), low or normal total iron-binding capacity, and a high ferritin level.

B) INCORRECT:

Iron-deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytic anemia, a low serum iron level, low iron saturation (iron-to-iron binding capacity), a low ferritin level, and high total iron-binding capacity and soluble transferrin receptor levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency usually have normal baseline hemoglobin and iron studies, because the anemia only occurs in response to oxidative stress.

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with sideroblastic anemia, iron studies show a high ferritin level, a high iron level, and low total iron-binding capacity.

E) CORRECT:

In patients with a chronic inflammation, such as rheumatoid arthritis, hepatic production of hepcidin, a major regulator of iron homeostasis, is increased. This causes reduced iron absorption in the duodenum and blockage of iron release from macrophages (so-called decreased iron “reutilization”).

In anemia of chronic inflammation (also called anemia of chronic disease), the reticulocyte count is inappropriately low for the level of anemia, serum iron levels are frankly low or at the lower end of the reference range, and the total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) and transferrin saturation level are reduced or normal. Ferritin levels are typically normal to increased. Iron deficiency can co-occur with anemia of chronic inflammation, in which case measuring the levels of soluble transferrin receptor can be helpful (they are elevated in iron deficiency but not in anemia of chronic inflammation). The molecular defect is inability to mobilize storage iron for new globin synthesis or defective iron reutilization. This form of anemia is unresponsive to supplemental iron.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with a high ferritin level, a low-normal iron level, and a low total iron-binding capacity is anemia of chronic inflammation, which is also characterized by a low reticulocyte count.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman reports a 2-month history of progressive fatigue, weakness, diminished exercise capacity, a 2.3-kg weight gain, and heavy, irregular menses. She was previously in overall good health.
On examination, her heart rate is 56 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 109/65 mm Hg. She moves and speaks slowly. Her oropharynx and sclera are unremarkable. She has mild conjunctival pallor. Her jugular venous pressure is normal. She has no lymphadenopathy. Her heart rhythm is regular. Her lungs are clear bilaterally. Her extremities show no edema or cyanosis.
Her laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
9.4

4200

Creatinine (mg/dL)

Which one of the following assessments is most likely to reveal the cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal and pelvic ultrasound would assess for causes of menometrorrhagia, such as uterine fibroids or endometrial cancer, and may be a reasonable next step if hypothyroidism is not present or if the menstrual abnormality persists despite treatment of hypothyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

General markers of inflammation, such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate, would not be diagnostically informative.

C) INCORRECT:

Heavy menstrual bleeding could result in iron-deficiency anemia, which is assessed by testing ferritin levels. However, iron-deficiency anemia is a microcytic anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

In the absence of kidney disease, one would expect the erythropoietin level to be elevated, but this finding would not rule out a primary marrow problem and would not be helpful in evaluating the cause of this patient’s anemia.

E) CORRECT:

The patient has a normocytic normochromic anemia. A common cause of this hematologic presentation is hypothyroidism; in this patient, the hypothyroidism may also be causing her heavy menstrual bleeding, which would further compound the anemia. An inappropriately slow heart rate for her level of anemia is also consistent with a hypothyroid state. Testing for abnormal thyroid function is indicated in the evaluation of a patient with suspected hypothyroidism.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a normocytic normochromic anemia in a 35-year-old woman with bradycardia and menometrorrhagia is hypothyroidism.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old gravida 0, para 0 woman born in El Salvador presents with fatigue. She has no known medical history and takes no medications. She has had regular menses since age 12 and average blood loss with each cycle. Her vital signs and physical examination are normal.
Laboratory results are as follows:

5,600,000
4,000,000–5,200,000

250,000

Ferritin (ng/mL)
60

13.8

Her peripheral-blood smear shows normal-appearing leukocytes and platelets with microcytic, hypochromic red cells and some target cells.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate in this patient?

choices.text: Iron level and total iron-binding capacity

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Microcytic anemias are seen in conditions in which heme or globin synthesis is impaired, including iron deficiency, lead poisoning, thalassemia, and, rarely, inflammation. The serum ferritin level is an indicator of cellular iron stores. The red-cell distribution width is normal in most patients with thalassemia but elevated in the other major cause of microcytic anemia, iron deficiency. The initial evaluation for the thalassemias is through hemoglobin electrophoresis or high-performance liquid chromatography, identifying variants associated with beta-thalassemia.

Key learning point: The diagnosis most suggested by microcytic anemia in a patient with a normal red-cell distribution width and normal iron stores is either alpha-thalassemia or beta-thalassemia.

B) INCORRECT:

An erythrocyte sedimentation rate is a nonspecific marker of inflammation and is unlikely to be diagnostically helpful.

C) INCORRECT:

A bone-marrow biopsy is helpful in evaluating for hematologic neoplasms or other causes of anemia, but this clinical scenario is highly suggestive of thalassemia; hemoglobin electrophoresis is the best next step.

D) INCORRECT:

Checking vitamin B12 and folate levels is not helpful. Deficiencies of those nutrients lead to a macrocytic anemia, although concurrent conditions associated with microcytic or normocytic anemias can decrease the mean corpuscular volume.

E) INCORRECT:

Iron level and total iron-binding capacity are unlikely to be informative in a patient with a normal ferritin level who has no features of an inflammatory disease.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman who has responded well to 6 months of treatment with oral methotrexate for symptomatic rheumatoid arthritis is found to have an abnormal complete blood count and other abnormal laboratory findings. She states that she does not experience dyspnea, fatigue, or neuropathy. She drinks approximately one serving of alcohol per week.
Her vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
11
12–16

108
80–100

10,000
4500–11,000

180,000
150,000–350,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)

220

Ferritin (ng/mL)
200
30–300


Transferrin saturation (%)
21

What is the most likely cause of this patient’s abnormal hemogram?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency causes a prolonged prothrombin time and prolonged international normalized ratio, which can increase bleeding risk. However, the patient has no evidence of bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

The low iron level and low total iron-binding capacity in this case are likely secondary to the effects of chronic inflammation, especially considering the patient’s history of rheumatoid arthritis and elevated ferritin. Anemia of chronic inflammation, however, does not typically cause macrocytosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Myelodysplastic syndrome would typically cause macrocytosis and can be difficult to distinguish from methotrexate-induced macrocytosis. However, it unlikely in this scenario because the other lineages (leukocytes and platelets) are normal.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron-deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytosis rather than macrocytosis. Furthermore, the patient's iron studies do not suggest iron deficiency. In iron deficiency, there is usually a low ferritin level and an increased total iron-binding capacity (TIBC). In addition, the transferrin saturation (calculated as the serum iron level divided by the serum TIBC level) is usually less than 10%; in this patient, it is 21%.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's macrocytosis is most likely due to treatment with methotrexate, which inhibits dihydrofolate reductase. Methotrexate and other drugs that inhibit DNA synthesis can cause macrocytosis.

Key learning point: A hematologic effect of treatment with methotrexate is macrocytosis.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old male college student reports experiencing profound fatigue. He is a competitive athlete and has been unable to play soccer for the past 2 weeks. He denies any other symptoms.
His hemoglobin level is 5.2 g/dL (reference range, 13.5–17.5), and his reticulocyte count is 0.45% red cells (0.5–2.5). His mean corpuscular volume, leukocyte count (including differential), and platelet count are normal. Examination of the peripheral-blood smear reveals normocytic, normochromic red cells and no schistocytes. Serum lactate dehydrogenase and haptoglobin levels are normal. A direct Coombs test is negative. A bone-marrow biopsy shows normal cellularity and no evidence of leukemia, but there is a complete lack of erythroid precursors.
Cytogenetic studies are normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is characterized by varying degrees of bone-marrow failure and cytopenias. In addition, there is chronic hemolysis related to the absence of CD55 and CD59 to prevent complement-mediated destruction of cells. This patient has no evidence of hemolysis, making this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with myelodysplastic syndrome usually have dysplasia, increased blasts, or cytogenic abnormalities on bone-marrow examination.

C) CORRECT:

Acquired pure red-cell aplasia is a rare disorder characterized by normocytic anemia and an absence of red-cell precursors in the blood (reticulocytes) and bone marrow. Leukocyte and platelet counts are generally normal. The condition is typically idiopathic but can occur in patients with hematologic malignancies (such as chronic lymphocytic leukemia), viral illnesses (such as parvovirus, HIV, or hepatitis C), or thymoma and in those taking certain medicines (such as phenytoin or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole). Treatment generally involves immunosuppression. Because of the association with thymoma and the possibility that the disease can be reversed with thymoma excision, the patient should have a chest radiograph.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young man with severe anemia, a low reticulocyte count, and a lack of erythroid precursors on bone-marrow examination is acquired pure red-cell aplasia.

D) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is associated with an elevated reticulocyte count, spherocytes on the peripheral smear, and a positive direct Coombs test.

E) INCORRECT:

Fanconi anemia is an inherited bone-marrow failure syndrome caused by variants in various genes involved in DNA repair. Affected patients usually present in childhood, although later presentations are possible. Patients do not typically present with isolated anemia. Most patients present with pancytopenia, although isolated thrombocytopenia can be seen. In addition, patients frequently have co-occurring congenital anomalies.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with fatigue that has worsened during the past few weeks. He has chronic kidney disease that is attributed to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs that he took regularly for back pain. He has no history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, cardiac disease, or lung disease. He states that he does not experience anorexia, vomiting, diarrhea, or lower urinary tract symptoms. He no longer takes any over-the-counter medications. A screening colonoscopy done 3 months ago was normal.
Vital signs and physical examination today are unremarkable.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:

Which one of the following tests is most appropriate next in this patient’s diagnostic evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anemia is a common complication of chronic kidney disease but is uncommon when the estimated glomerular filtration rate is >45 mL/min/1.73m2 . This patient’s decline in hemoglobin is out of proportion to the decline in renal function and is substantial for a 6-month period. In these cases, further evaluation is warranted. This patient has already undergone iron studies, vitamin B12 and folate testing, and screening colonoscopy, all of which were normal. The most appropriate next step — given his increased serum creatinine level, hypercalcemia with a low-normal parathyroid hormone level (ruling out primary hyperparathyroidism), and proteinuria — is serum protein immunoelectrophoresis to test for multiple myeloma.

Anemia is present in approximately 73% of patients at the time of multiple myeloma diagnosis. It is generally related to marrow infiltration or renal impairment, which occurs as a result of direct tubular damage from excess protein load, dehydration, and hypercalcemia.

Key learning point: In a patient with hypercalcemia, proteinuria, and anemia disproportionate to the degree of chronic kidney disease, a prompt diagnostic evaluation should be done to evaluate for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

B) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis would not explain this patient’s anemia and increasing proteinuria.

C) INCORRECT:

Sleep-disordered breathing would not explain this patient’s anemia and increasing proteinuria.

D) INCORRECT:

Kidney ultrasound would have a low diagnostic yield in a patient without obstructive urinary symptoms whose clinical findings indicate a systemic disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin A intoxication is a rare cause of hypercalcemia but would not explain this patient’s anemia and increasing proteinuria.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman presents for a health maintenance visit. She reports progressive fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. She has also had persistent hip pain for the past 6 months that is partially relieved by daily naproxen.
She has a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 124/64 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 95% while breathing ambient air. She appears pale and has clear lungs and a regular heart rate without murmur. Examination of her extremities reveals right-knee crepitus and diminished range of motion of the right hip.
A complete blood count (CBC) was normal one year ago. Today’s CBC results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
5500
4500–11,000



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
7.8
12.0–16.0



Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
70
80–100


Platelet count (per mm3)
350,000
150,000–350,000


Reticulocytes (% red cells)
1.0
0.5–2.5


Red-cell distribution width (%)
18.0
11.5–14.5


A peripheral blood smear is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following tests should be ordered to establish a diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's laboratory findings are consistent with microcytic anemia, and her peripheral blood smear reveals microcytosis, hypochromia, and pencil cells. The most common cause of microcytic hypochromic anemia is iron deficiency. The diagnosis can be confirmed by iron studies, which include serum ferritin level, serum iron level, transferrin or total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), and iron saturation.

A low serum ferritin level remains the most specific finding of low total-body iron stores and confirms the diagnosis of iron deficiency. Aging and inflammation can falsely elevate the ferritin level; therefore, a normal ferritin laboratory result (up to 100 ng/mL) does not always rule out iron deficiency. Transferrin saturation is low with iron deficiency and anemia of inflammation. TIBC is elevated with iron-deficiency anemia, although it is not very sensitive. Serum iron levels are low with anemia of inflammation and can be falsely elevated with oral iron supplementation.

Key learning point: The most common cause of microcytic anemia is iron deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobin electrophoresis is useful in diagnosing congenital anemias such as hemoglobinopathy or thalassemia. A usual feature of the microcytic anemia associated with thalassemia is a normal red-cell distribution width. This patient’s finding of a normal complete blood count one year ago rules out this possibility.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency is a cause of macrocytic anemia. It occasionally coexists with other nutritional deficiencies in conditions associated with malabsorption. Homocysteine levels may be elevated when associated with vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. Given that this patient has microcytic anemia, measurement of vitamin B12 and homocysteine levels would not be helpful in confirming a diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency is a cause of macrocytic anemia. It occasionally coexists with other nutritional deficiencies in conditions associated with malabsorption. Homocysteine levels may be elevated when associated with vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. Given that this patient has microcytic anemia, measurement of vitamin B12 and homocysteine levels would not be helpful in confirming a diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Bone-marrow iron staining is the gold standard for diagnosis of iron deficiency, but it is too invasive to be used in routine practice for the purpose of diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old woman with Alzheimer disease who resides in a nursing home is referred for evaluation of a new anemia. The staff noticed that she has been more lethargic and less interactive during the past 3 months, and a fingerstick test conducted there revealed a hemoglobin level of 7.1 g/dL (reference range, 12.0–16.0).
On examination, the patient appears pale. She is alert and oriented to name and place but is confused about the year. Neurologic examination reveals a shuffling, broad-based gait and diminished sensation to light touch and pinprick.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
6.8
12.0–16.0



Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
112
80–100


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
4200
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
140,000
150,000–350,000


Reticulocyte count (per mm3)
23,000
20,000–80,000


Haptoglobin (mg/dL)
30

Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
185

Vitamin B12 (pg/mL)
262
