Urine testing for free hemoglobin and hemosiderin is negative. A peripheral blood smear is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following additional laboratory tests should this patient undergo next?

choices.text: Flow cytometry for CD55 and CD59 proteins

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A direct Coombs test is used to rule out autoimmune hemolytic anemia, but this diagnosis is unlikely in this patient. Her peripheral blood smear shows no spherocytes, and there is no laboratory evidence of hemolysis (her lactate dehydrogenase and haptoglobin levels are normal).

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s peripheral blood smear shows many large, oval-shaped erythrocytes (macrocytic anemia), and the single neutrophil has at least six visible lobes (neutrophil hypersegmentation). Clinical evaluation of macrocytic anemia begins with evaluation of the most likely causes, such as nutritional deficiencies (e.g., vitamin B12 deficiency), excess alcohol use, myelodysplastic syndrome, and (more rarely) severe hypothyroidism.

Vitamin B12 deficiency has many causes, including diseases of the ileum (e.g., inflammatory bowel conditions such as Crohn disease), gastrectomy, pernicious anemia (related to autoantibodies against intrinsic factor), excess alcohol use, and lack of adequate dietary intake (e.g., because of adherence to a strict vegan diet). Mild or subclinical manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are common in older adults and may stem from one or more of the aforementioned factors, as well as from other factors that contribute to vitamin B12 malabsorption, such as gastric atrophy, intestinal overgrowth related to antibiotic treatment, and long-term use of certain medications (histamine-2-receptor antagonists, proton pump inhibitors, and metformin).

In vitamin B12 deficiency, there is an increase in red blood cell turnover in the marrow, and the lactate dehydrogenase level is often at the upper limit of normal or slightly elevated. Although folate deficiency is uncommon now (given the fortification of many foods with folic acid), it can coexist with vitamin B12 deficiency, so testing for both is important when vitamin B12 deficiency is suspected.

A vitamin B12 level <200 pg/mL has a specificity of 95% to 100% for vitamin B12 deficiency, whereas a vitamin B12 level >300 pg/mL (normal range) makes the diagnosis of vitamin B12 deficiency very unlikely. When a borderline result of 200 to 300 pg/mL is identified in a patient with macrocytic anemia (as in this patient), a diagnosis of vitamin B12 deficiency is possible, and further testing should be undertaken. Serum levels of biologic intermediates of vitamin B12 production (e.g., methylmalonic acid and homocysteine) can be more sensitive for vitamin B12 deficiencythan serum levels of vitamin B12 are. Notably, only the homocysteine level is elevated in patients with folate deficiency. Treatment of vitamin B12 deficiency normalizes these metabolic intermediates.

Because folate can correct the marrow defect from vitamin B12 deficiency, many older patients come to medical attention with neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency, including worsening cognition, balance problems, gait problems, numbness, and paresthesias. Folate deficiency is not generally associated with neurologic signs and symptoms.

Key learning point: In a patient with a severe macrocytic anemia associated with neurologic findings, an elevated serum methylmalonic acid level is very specific for identifying vitamin B12 deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

The absence of hemolysis, microangiopathic changes, and red-cell agglutination on this patient’s blood smear also rule out the possibility of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura and cold agglutinin disease. Thus, there is no basis for measuring the ADAMTS13 enzyme level or cold agglutinin titer in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

The absence of hemolysis, microangiopathic changes, and red-cell agglutination on this patient’s blood smear also rule out the possibility of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura and cold agglutinin disease. Thus, there is no basis for measuring the ADAMTS13 enzyme level or cold agglutinin titer in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry for the glycophosphatidylinositol-linked proteins CD55 and CD59 is used to test for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, but this patient does not have reticulocytosis, an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level, or any other signs or symptoms of this condition.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy who has been a vegetarian for the past year presents for a sports preparticipation examination. He is an avid runner and wants to join the cross-country team at school.
His weight is in the 45th percentile. He takes no medications or supplements. An in-office point-of-care hemoglobin level is 10.5 g/dL (reference range, 13.0–16.0).
Which one of the following laboratory tests should be ordered next to evaluate this patient's anemia?

choices.text: Complete blood count with red-cell indices

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fecal occult blood testing could be used to search for a source of iron loss but not until after iron deficiency is definitively diagnosed.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobin electrophoresis would be indicated if an underlying inherited hemoglobinopathy, such as sickle cell disease or a thalassemia, was suspected. It is not the appropriate initial step in evaluating a low screening hemoglobin level.

C) INCORRECT:

Much of the iron in the body is stored in ferritin, a cellular protein. A low ferritin level would indicate iron deficiency; however, a normal ferritin level does not necessarily mean that there is no iron deficiency, because ferritin is an acute-phase reactant. It is important to first obtain a complete blood count with red-cell indices to characterize the anemia. Then, iron studies and a ferritin level can be obtained and interpreted.

D) INCORRECT:

Folate levels would not be measured unless the complete blood count identified macroovalocytes and megaloblasts, concerning for folate deficiency. People who practice vegetarianism often consume enough fruits, grains, and green leafy vegetables and do not become folate deficient.

E) CORRECT:

Sports preparticipation examinations represent an opportunity to identify adolescents at risk for iron deficiency and iron-deficiency anemia. Although iron deficiency is less common in boys than girls, this patient is at risk because of his vegetarian diet and participation in an endurance sport.

Laboratory evidence of iron deficiency occurs in stages, with initial preservation of red-cell morphology and count despite a decrease in iron stores. As iron depletion continues, the red-cell distribution width increases, ferritin levels are measurably low, and the classic picture of iron-deficiency anemia with hypochromia and microcytosis appears.

When a screening hemoglobin level is found to be abnormally low, as in this case, the next step is a complete blood count with red-cell indices.

Key learning point: The first step in diagnostic evaluation for iron-deficiency anemia is a complete blood count with red-cell indices.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl presents for her first medical visit after immigrating to the United States. She has generally been healthy and takes no medications. She reached menarche at age 13 and has normal menses, with moderate flow that lasts 5 days.
Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 95 beats per minute. Her physical examination is normal.
Laboratory analysis is performed as part of screening for a new immigrant. All results are normal with the exception of some elements of the complete blood count:



Patient value
Reference range

9000
4500–13,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
9.5
12.0–16.0


Hematocrit (%)
30.5
36.0–46.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
350,000
150,000–450,000

71
78–102


Erythrocyte count (per mm3)
5,900,000
4,100,000–5,100,000
