11.5
11.5–14.5


Microcytosis, hypochromasia, and target cells are noted on the blood smear.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to confirm the suspected diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measurement of vitamin B12 levels is helpful in patients with macrocytic anemia and an elevated MCV, which are associated with vitamin B12 deficiency, but this patient has microcytic anemia with a low MCV.

B) INCORRECT:

Haptoglobin testing is appropriate for suspected hemolytic anemia, but this patient has no history — or evidence on blood smear — to suggest hemolysis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s complete blood count reveals microcytic anemia (low hematocrit associated with low mean corpuscular volume [MCV]), and the blood smear shows small pale cells (microcytosis with hypochromasia) with some target cells. The main types of microcytic anemia are iron-deficiency anemia, thalassemia, sideroblastic anemia, and anemia of inflammation.

Beta-thalassemia trait (also known as beta-thalassemia minor) and iron deficiency are the two most common microcytic anemias in children, and the red-cell distribution width (RDW) and Mentzer index (mean corpuscular volume/erythrocyte count) can be used to help distinguish between them. The combination of a normal RDW and a Mentzer index <13 (as seen in this case) is consistent with beta- or alpha-thalassemia trait, whereas a high RDW and a Mentzer index >13 is more consistent with iron-deficiency anemia. Although the Mentzer index can be used to screen for thalassemia, it is not diagnostic.

Sideroblastic anemia is a consequence of problems with heme synthesis and is typically associated with a high RDW.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an adolescent who has microcytic anemia with a normal red-cell distribution width is beta-thalassemia trait.

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of ferritin levels is appropriate for suspected iron-deficiency anemia, and lead testing can be considered if lead poisoning is thought to be the cause of the iron-deficiency anemia. However, this patient's RDW and Mentzer index are more consistent with thalassemia than iron-deficiency anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of ferritin levels is appropriate for suspected iron-deficiency anemia. However, this patient's RDW and Mentzer index are more consistent with thalassemia than iron-deficiency anemia.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy presents for follow-up 2 weeks after his parents brought him in with cough, rhinorrhea, and pallor.
Today, he has a temperature of 36.7°C, a heart rate of 170 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 35 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 88/42 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 100% while breathing ambient air. Physical examination is notable only for pallor.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
7000
6000–17,500


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
5
10.5–13.5


Platelet count
300,000
150,000–450,000


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
80
70–86


Reticulocyte count (% red cells)
0.3
0.5–2.5


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although Diamond-Blackfan anemia also manifests with reticulocytopenia, the anemia is usually more severe (with a hemoglobin concentration of 2 to 4 g/dL), and the MCV is increased; patients also often have an elevated hemoglobin F level. Given that this disorder is a congenital illness, it typically manifests in infants as a progressive anemia and is not as classically preceded by a viral illness. About half of patients have additional congenital abnormalities evident on physical examination, including thumb abnormalities ranging from subluxation to a bifid thumb. Treatment often includes supportive transfusions and glucocorticoids, with hematopoietic cell transplantation in glucocorticoid-refractory patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the clinical presentation of this patient could be consistent with autoimmune hemolytic anemia, as it can be triggered by Mycoplasma pneumoniae, this condition would typically be associated with an increased reticulocyte response (rather than the reticulocytopenia seen in this patient). In addition, patients with autoimmune hemolytic anemia may be jaundiced in the setting of an indirect hyperbilirubinemia (bilirubin being released from the destruction of erythrocytes).

C) CORRECT:

Transient erythroblastopenia of childhood is a benign, self-limiting condition most often seen in otherwise healthy children (1 to 4 years of age) after a viral illness. Patients present with a hemoglobin level in the range of 3 to 9 g/dL, a normal mean corpuscular volume (MCV), and reticulocytopenia; they tend to have signs of severe anemia but are usually hemodynamically stable. Red-cell transfusion can be given if indicated for hemodynamic support, but treatment is mainly supportive care and watchful waiting. There is no evidence that glucocorticoids help improve the anemia. Recovery usually occurs in 1 to 2 months, with no long-term hematologic problems.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a toddler who presents, shortly after a viral illness, with a low hemoglobin level, a normal mean corpuscular volume, and reticulocytopenia is transient erythroblastopenia of childhood.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron-deficiency anemia often occurs in toddlers with high milk intake because of the milk’s low iron content, its occasional association with occult blood loss in the intestines, and calcium’s inhibition of iron absorption. However, iron deficiency is associated with a microcytic anemia, and in a patient with a hemoglobin concentration of 5 g/dL, the mean corpuscular volume would be low (unlike in this patient).

E) INCORRECT:

Although Fanconi anemia is also an anemia associated with reticulocytopenia, it is a congenital bone-marrow failure syndrome that is associated with pancytopenia and a macrocytic anemia. In addition, patients are likely to present with a number of physical findings, such as thumb or radial ray abnormalities, café au lait spots, short stature, endocrinopathies, and other clinical manifestations, none of which are seen in this patient. Patients with Fanconi anemia are also at increased risk for both hematologic neoplasms and solid tumors.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl reports 4-month history of fatigue. She had infectious mononucleosis 8 weeks ago. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 days with moderate flow. Examination shows pale conjunctivae and scaling of the corners of the mouth. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.3 g/dL


Erythrocyte count
3.7 million/mm3


Mean corpuscular volume
74 μm3


Leukocyte count
6,000/mm3



Platelet count
280,000/mm3



Reticulocyte count
0.4%


A peripheral blood smear shows erythrocytes of unequal sizes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobin electrophoresis is used to diagnose inherited hematologic disorders associated with abnormal hemoglobin production such as sickle cell disease and thalassemia. Although thalassemia is an important cause of microcytic anemia, patients with thalassemia typically have a Mentzer index < 13, a normal or high reticulocyte count, and, unless the patient has beta-thalassemia major, significant anisocytosis would not be expected. A different test would be more appropriate in the initial workup of microcytic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

The direct Coombs test is used to diagnose autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA), which is associated with recent viral infection (e.g., infectious mononucleosis). However, hemolytic anemia most commonly presents with a normal or increased MCV and an increased reticulocyte count.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 is measured in order to diagnose vitamin B12 deficiency, which would cause anemia and occasionally, angular cheilitis. However, vitamin B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia rather than the microcytic anemia seen in this patient. Instead, the patient would have other features such as glossitis or neuropathy.

D) CORRECT:

Iron deficiency is the most common cause of microcytic anemia, especially in women due to blood loss during menstruation, which can gradually decrease the body's iron stores. Ferritin measurement is the first-line test for assessing the body's iron stores and screening for iron deficiency anemia (IDA). The changes associated with IDA include decreased ferritin, increased transferrin, and decreased transferrin saturation. Further work-up would be needed to ascertain whether abnormal bleeding or malabsorption may be causing the iron deficiency.

Key learning point: Ferritin measurement is the first-line test to confirm iron deficiency anemia, the most common cause of microcytic anemia, especially in menstruating women.

E) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow biopsy is used to diagnose diseases such as aplastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndrome, and hematologic malignancies. It may also be used to directly measure bone marrow iron stores in patients with suspected iron deficiency anemia when first-line testing does not lead to a diagnosis. However, an invasive test such as bone marrow biopsy would not be indicated for initial work-up.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, pallor, angular cheilitis, decreased hemoglobin, decreased mean corpuscular volume, a Mentzer index > 13, and anisocytosis. These features are consistent with the most common form of anemia.

questions.text:
A 10-month-old boy is brought to the office for a well-child examination. Medical history is unremarkable. His maternal uncle has alpha thalassemia trait. His diet consists exclusively of breast milk. He can walk with one hand held and can throw a small ball. He can pick up an object between his thumb and index finger. He can say “mama” and “dada.” Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
72 μm3


Red blood cell distribution width

18% 


Reticulocyte count
0.6%


Leukocyte count
7,200/mm3



Platelet count
280,000/mm3



Which of the following is the most likely cause of these laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the hemoglobin alpha chain can cause alpha thalassemia trait, which can manifest with microcytic anemia. This patient's family history of alpha thalassemia trait increases the likelihood of him having this condition. However, patients with alpha thalassemia trait typically have a low or normal RDW. Patients who carry 3–4 defective alleles in the genes that encode the α-globin chain develop hemoglobin H disease, which manifests with jaundice and anemia at birth; this patient's medical history is unremarkable.

B) INCORRECT:

Lead toxicity can rarely cause mild microcytic anemia. The most common manifestations of symptomatic lead toxicity are neurocognitive deficits. However, this patient is meeting developmental milestones for a 12-month-old infant. Moreover, he does not have clear risk factors for lead exposure (e.g., living in housing that was built before the 1970s).

C) INCORRECT:

Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by defective erythrocyte membrane proteins, which lead to premature destruction of erythrocytes, extravascular hemolysis, and hemolytic anemia. However, spherocytosis typically manifests with normocytic anemia and reticulocytosis. Patients may be asymptomatic or develop jaundice, splenomegaly, and/or black pigment gallstones.

D) CORRECT:

Insufficient iron intake can cause iron deficiency anemia (IDA), which typically manifests with microcytic anemia and an increased RDW with no compensatory increase in reticulocytes. While IDA is usually asymptomatic, severe cases can manifest with lethargy, pallor, and irritability. IDA is common in infants > 6 months of age who are exclusively breastfed, only fed cow's milk, or who were born prematurely. Because IDA can lead to neurocognitive deficits, iron supplementation is recommended for exclusively breastfed infants starting from the age of 4 months (or at the age of 2 weeks for premature infants) and until the intake of iron-rich food is sufficient. Treatment of IDA consists of oral iron supplementation and dietary changes.

E) INCORRECT:

An increased HbS concentration is seen in patients with sickle cell disease, which can be asymptomatic during the first year of life, as the production of HbF decreases and HbS concentration increases. Patients typically have a high RDW and chronic hemolytic anemia, which is often normocytic rather than microcytic. In addition, patients have reticulocytosis because immature reticulocytes are released to help maintain oxygenation; this patient has a normal reticulocyte count.
questions.hint: This patient's laboratory studies show microcytic anemia and an increased red blood cell distribution width (RDW).

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents for the evaluation of fatigue for several weeks. He quit doing sports at school because of low energy. The patient's academic performance has declined recently. He spends most of his time in the basement playing video games and eating bowls of milk and cereal. His mother has Hashimoto thyroiditis and his father has major depressive disorder. Examination shows conjunctival pallor, inflammation and fissuring of the corners of the mouth, and concavity of the fingernails. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.5 g/dL



Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)
76 μm3



Red cell distribution width (RDW)
18%


Leukocyte count
7,000/mm3



Platelet count
290,000/mm3



Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

L-thyroxine is the treatment of choice in patients with hypothyroidism. This patient has a positive family history of Hashimoto thyroiditis and presents with fatigue, which is a typical feature of hypothyroidism. However, hypothyroidism is typically associated with normocytic or macrocytic nonmegaloblastic anemia and the absence of additional features of hypothyroidism (e.g., cold intolerance, dry skin, hair loss, weight gain, constipation, myopathy) makes the diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 supplementation is indicated in patients with vitamin B12 deficiency, which may manifest with clinical and laboratory findings of anemia (e.g., decreased hemoglobin, fatigue, low energy, and conjunctival pallor) and angular cheilitis. A restrictive diet (e.g., mainly cereal) is an important cause of vitamin deficiencies in general. However, vitamin B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia (↑ MCV), or more specifically, megaloblastic anemia, rather than microcytic anemia.

C) CORRECT:

Oral iron supplementation is the initial treatment of choice for iron deficiency anemia (IDA). This patient's high consumption of cereal puts him at risk for developing this condition because cereal is typically low in iron. Although fortification of cereals has helped reduce nutritional deficiency of iron in the United States, the concomitant intake of cow's milk disrupts iron absorption. Therefore, this patient should also receive counseling on how to improve dietary iron intake. Patients with IDA should also be assessed for other potential causes of IDA (e.g., blood loss).

Other common laboratory findings in IDA include decreased ferritin, increased transferrin, decreased transferrin saturation, and decreased mean corpuscular hemoglobin (hypochromic anemia).

D) INCORRECT:

Succimer is the preferred pharmacotherapy for lead poisoning in pediatric patients. High levels of lead interfere with hemoglobin synthesis and may result in microcytic anemia. While this patient's anemia could be caused by lead poisoning, the lack of additional symptoms, such as learning difficulties or developmental delay (due to encephalopathy), Burton's lines, and involvement of the GI tract, kidneys, or peripheral nerves (e.g., wrist and foot drop), make the diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine, are the preferred pharmacotherapy in pediatric patients with major depressive disorder (MDD). MDD can manifest with fatigue, low energy, social withdrawal (e.g., playing video games alone), and loss of interest (e.g., in school sports). Despite the presence of these features and a positive family history, this patient's symptoms are not sufficient to make a diagnosis of MDD (requires ≥ 5 symptoms of depression for at least 2 weeks, with at least one of the symptoms being depressed mood or anhedonia). Most importantly, MDD does not explain this patient's anemia.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, conjunctival pallor, angular cheilitis, koilonychia, decreased hemoglobin, decreased MCV, and increased RDW. These features are suggestive of the most common form of anemia.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of bilateral hand pain and swelling. Two weeks ago, the patient had a low-grade fever and lace-like rash on her arms and trunk for several days. The patient appears to be in distress. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.4°F), pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 25/min. The dorsum of her hands and fingers are erythematous, swollen, warm, and tender to palpation. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.1 g/dL and leukocyte count is 8000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows numerous sickle to crescent-shaped red blood cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention to reduce the recurrence of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with SCD, blood transfusions are indicated primarily for symptomatic treatment of acute complications (e.g., hemolytic, aplastic, or sequestration crises), preventing chronic complications (stroke), or before surgery. Recommendations vary among institutions but are largely determined by decreases from the baseline Hb levels (typically between ∼ 7–11 g/dL) and the patient's condition. For example, RBC transfusion may be considered after a fall of 2 g/dL and/or if the patient has severe symptoms. This patient's history of recent fever and a lace-like rash suggests parvovirus B19 infection, which is associated with an increased risk for aplastic crisis in patients with SCD. However, her normal leukocyte count and only moderate anemia make aplastic crisis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is indicated in all infants > 9 months, children, and adolescents with sickle cell anemia regardless of symptom severity because it reduces the incidence of acute vasoocclusive episodes and improves survival. The mechanism of action of hydroxyurea is not entirely understood, but the agent likely stimulates erythropoiesis and increases fetal hemoglobin so that the amount of sickled hemoglobin is proportionally reduced.

Indications for hydroxyurea therapy for adults with SCD include frequent (≥ 3 episodes/year) acute pain episodes or other vasoocclusive events, severe symptomatic anemia, and a history of severe and/or recurrent acute chest syndrome.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Numerous crescent-shaped erythrocytes, known as “sickle cells,” can be seen (examples indicated by blue overlay; two normal erythrocytes are indicated by arrowheads for comparison). Erythrocytes with a red center and a white contouring ring, known as “target cells” (yellow overlay; cf. illustration) are visible at the bottom of the image.

Sickle cells are pathognomonic of sickle-cell disease. Target cells can be found in sickle-cell disease and other hemoglobinopathies.

C) INCORRECT:

Red cell exchange (RCE) transfusions are used in patients with SCD. However, RCE is typically used to treat acute life-threatening SCD complications such as ischemic stroke and is not considered a first-line or long-term treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are used in the treatment of rheumatological diseases (e.g., juvenile rheumatoid arthritis). These diseases can lead to low-grade fevers, rashes, and pain in the extremities. However, this patient's blood smear, acute onset of symptoms, lack of morning stiffness, and generalized swelling of both hands make a complication of SCD more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Although penicillin prophylaxis would be indicated in this patient (and all other patients with SCD until the age of five), it would do nothing to prevent this patient's current ailment in the future, which is caused by vasoocclusions of the small bones of the hand rather than a bacterial infection.
questions.hint: This patient's peripheral blood smear shows numerous sickle to crescent-shaped red blood cells (i.e., sickle cells), indicating sickle cell disease (SCD). Dactylitis is often the first manifestation of vasoocclusive episodes, which can also cause fever.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the office for the evaluation of fatigue since he returned from visiting family in South Africa one week ago. The day after he returned, he had fever, chills, and diffuse joint pain for 3 days. His symptoms improved with acetaminophen. He was born at term and has been healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.8 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
68 μm3



Red cell distribution width

14% (N = 13–15)


Hemoglobin A2

6% (N < 3.5)


A peripheral smear shows microcytic, hypochromic erythrocytes and target cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is used to treat sickle cell anemia, which is also associated with target cells, and may manifest with fever, fatigue, and joint pain during a vaso-occlusive crisis. However, Hb electrophoresis would reveal elevated HbS, not an elevated HbA2. Additionally, sickle cells would be visible in a peripheral smear. This patient's recent fever, chills, and joint pains were likely due to a benign viral infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Succimer is used to treat lead poisoning, which can cause microcytic anemia. However, the peripheral blood smear would show basophilic stippling and Hb electrophoresis would not show elevated HbA2.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with beta thalassemia minor are usually monitored without any additional treatment. The microcytic anemia caused by the condition is often confused with iron deficiency anemia. However, a normal RDW, elevated HbA2 level, and target cells indicate beta thalassemia minor as a much more likely cause (see “Interpretation of Hb-electrophoresis results for thalassemia” table).

This patient's history of fatigue, fever, and arthralgia is probably due to an acute viral infection. Episodic folic acid supplementation may be considered during acute infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Pyridoxine is used to treat sideroblastic anemia, which is also a possible cause of microcytic anemia and target cells. However, HbA2 would be normal, the RDW would be elevated, and the peripheral smear would also show ringed sideroblasts with prussian blue stain.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral iron supplementation is used to treat iron deficiency anemia, which also manifests as microcytic anemia. However, it is usually associated with elevated RDW, and an elevated HbA2 level and target cells would not be expected.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features consistent with beta thalassemia minor: mild anemia, decreased MCV, target cells (RBCs with dark center and rim separated by a pale ring), a normal red cell distribution width (RDW), and increased HbA2 levels.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis comes to the office for a follow-up examination one week after being discharged from the hospital. While she was in the hospital, she received acetaminophen and erythropoietin. This patient most likely has which of the following additional conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Factor VIII deficiency is seen in hemophilia A, a blood clotting disorder that leads to serious bleeding (e.g., hemarthrosis, muscular or soft tissue hematomas). Usually only males are affected, as it is primarily an X-linked recessive disease. Treatment includes desmopressin, or in severe cases, substitution of factor VIII. Substitution of EPO would not be effective.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency can impair the coagulation cascade, leading to pathological bleeding. Symptoms include ecchymosis, hematomas, and hemarthroses. Anemia might be seen, but it would not be due to reduced RBC production, so substitution of EPO would not be effective.

C) INCORRECT:

Agranulocytosis is a condition characterized by severe leukopenia. Treatment may involve granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) but not EPO.

D) CORRECT:

Anemia of chronic disease (ACD) occurs in patients with a chronic disease process such as inflammation (e.g., this patient's rheumatoid arthritis), malignancy, infection, or renal failure. ACD is characterized by reduced erythropoietic response to both endogenous and exogenous EPO. However, high doses of EPO can overcome this hyporesponsiveness and are recommended in these patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is an acquired form of a low platelet count secondary to antibody formation against GpIIb/IIIa on platelets. ITP does not perturb the structure or function of WBCs, RBCs, or coagulation factors (i.e., isolated thrombocytopenia). It can be treated with thrombopoietin or thrombopoietin receptor agonists, but EPO would not be effective in treating thrombocytopenia.
questions.hint: Erythropoietin (EPO) stimulates erythroid cell division and proliferation and inhibits erythroid progenitor apoptosis.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents with worsening fatigue and an unintentional 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months. She also reports having had an unusual appetite for soil and clay for several months. She has a history of osteoarthritis of the knees, for which she takes acetaminophen. Her pulse is 116/min and blood pressure is 125/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diffuse teeth abrasions and dirt in the sublingual folds. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's fatigue, pica, and tachycardia indicate iron deficiency anemia (IDA). The combination of IDA and unintentional weight loss in a 63-year-old patient raises concern for chronic gastrointestinal bleeding from colorectal cancer (CRC). A stool guaiac test, which can detect the presence of occult blood in the stool, is likely to be positive. Following a stool guaiac test, this patient should undergo further diagnostic studies (e.g., colonoscopy and esophagogastroduodenoscopy) in order to confirm the underlying source of bleeding.

IDA from chronic occult blood loss in the absence of obstructive symptoms is especially common in patients with right-sided colon carcinoma. In contrast, left-sided colon carcinomas more commonly manifest with changes in bowel habits, blood-streaked stools, and colicky abdominal pain, while rectal carcinomas often manifest with diminished caliber of stools, tenesmus, and hematochezia.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is observed in patients with hypothyroidism. Hypothyroidism often manifests with fatigue, weight gain, constipation, bradycardia, and cold intolerance. This patient's weight loss and pica are not consistent with hypothyroidism, which makes elevated TSH levels an unlikely additional finding.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum lead concentration is caused by the consumption of substances contaminated with lead (e.g., due to pica). Common sources include paint, particularly in older houses, and contaminated water. Lead poisoning typically causes anemia (due to increased free radical formation and ensuing hemolysis), which manifests with fatigue and tachycardia. However, this patient does not have other expected findings such as abdominal pain, headaches, irritability, reduced cognition, or gingival lead lines.

D) INCORRECT:

A decreased CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is seen in patients with immunodeficiency. Unintentional weight loss and chronic fatigue can be signs of chronic conditions resulting in immunodeficiency (e.g., HIV infection). However, further symptoms, particularly an increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections, are expected in patients with a decreased CD4+ T-lymphocyte count. Moreover, immunodeficiency is not associated with pica, making this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

A positive Schilling test indicates vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to macrocytic anemia that manifests with fatigue and tachycardia. Important risk factors for the development of vitamin B12 deficiency include malnutrition (e.g., in veganism or restricted dietary intake due to anorexia nervosa), inflammatory bowel disease, and bariatric surgery. Patients with this condition may present with a variety of symptoms, including glossitis, neurological symptoms (e.g., diminished executive functioning and personality changes), and gait abnormalities (due to peripheral neuropathy or subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord), none of which are seen here. Furthermore, vitamin B12 deficiency is not typically associated with unintentional weight loss or pica.
questions.hint: This patient's unusual appetite for soil and clay, resulting in teeth abrasions and dirt in the sublingual folds, should raise concern for pica, which may be associated with a particular micronutrient deficiency.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of persistent cough, exertional dyspnea, and progressive fatigue. She has bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. She denies any dietary changes, gastrointestinal symptoms, recent travel, or medication use. Physical examination is normal. Biopsy of mediastinal lymph nodes reveals noncaseating granulomas (see lab results).


Heart rate
82/min


Blood pressure
120/80 mm Hg


Temperature
37.4°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
95 g/L
120 - 160 g/L


Ferritin
350 μg/L
20 - 120 μg/L


Iron
6 μmol/L
9 - 30.4 μmol/L


Transferrin
2 g/L
2.3 - 3.9 g/L



Which of the following best explains her laboratory findings?

choices.text: Erythrocyte autoantibody-mediated hemolysis from systemic inflammation
Increased gastrointestinal blood loss from unrecognized ulceration
Impaired release of iron from storage due to increased hepcidin
Inadequate iron intake leading to depletion of stored iron

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hemolytic anemia presents with elevated lactate dehydrogenase, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, increased reticulocytes, and a positive Coombs test. The patient's low serum iron, high ferritin, and low transferrin indicate altered iron handling due to chronic inflammation, not hemolysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal blood loss typically causes iron deficiency anemia, with low serum iron, low ferritin, and increased transferrin. This patient's low serum iron, low transferrin, and high ferritin suggest iron sequestration due to inflammation, not depletion from blood loss. The absence of gastrointestinal symptoms further supports this.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic inflammatory conditions, such as sarcoidosis, elevate inflammatory cytokines like interleukin-6, which stimulate hepcidin production in the liver. Hepcidin binds to ferroportin on macrophages and enterocytes, causing its degradation and inhibiting iron release from storage and intestinal absorption. This results in low serum iron despite adequate or increased iron stores, reflected by high ferritin levels. The reduced iron availability for erythropoiesis leads to anemia, characterized by low hemoglobin, low serum iron, low transferrin, and high ferritin.

Key learning point: Anemia of chronic disease is characterized by normal or elevated ferritin levels and is commonly associated with chronic inflammatory conditions such as sarcoidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Inadequate iron intake leads to low ferritin and high transferrin due to depleted stores. This patient has high ferritin and low transferrin, indicating iron sequestration from inflammation, not dietary deficiency. The presence of noncaseating granulomas supports an inflammatory process.

questions.text:
You are seeing a 20-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever and lethargy. He reports occasional palpitations and shortness of breath during this period. His medical history includes asthma and sickle cell disease. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His current medications are inhaled albuterol, hydroxyurea, and folic acid. He appears fatigued. His temperature is 38.4°C, pulse is 122/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. On examination, he has pale conjunctivae and a midsystolic ejection murmur on cardiac examination. The remainder of the examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood

65 g/L (125–170)


Mean corpuscular volume (MCV), blood
82 fL (80–100)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
5.5 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Platelet count, blood
165 × 109/L (130–380)


Reticulocyte percentage, blood

0.2% (0.5–1.5)


Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is a medication used in SCD that effectively increases HbF levels and reduces the frequency of severe vaso-occlusive crises. Hydroxyurea can cause anemia and decreased reticulocyte count due to myelosuppression. Hydroxyurea-induced myelosuppression typically results in pancytopenia, in which platelets and leukocytes are also decreased. However, this patient has a normal leukocyte and platelet count. Moreover, hydroxyurea-induced myelosuppression develops gradually over weeks to months rather than acutely.

B) INCORRECT:

Dysfunctional erythrocyte membrane proteins (e.g., ankyrin, spectrin) are seen in patients with hereditary spherocytosis (HS). Although HS may manifest with aplastic crisis, it is not known to be a cause of aplastic crisis in patients with SCD.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with hyperhemolysis present with acute onset anemia. However, they do not have bone marrow suppression and their reticulocyte count is therefore increased in order to compensate for the decreased hemoglobin.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's anemia is most likely due to an infection with parvovirus B19, which is commonly associated with a transient cessation of erythropoiesis. In otherwise healthy individuals, red blood cells (RBCs) have a long lifespan and clinically relevant drops in hemoglobin are very rare. Patients with underlying hemolytic anemias such as SCD and hereditary spherocytosis, however, have RBCs with a decreased lifespan. In these patients, the transient cessation of erythropoiesis may result in an acute, severe drop in hemoglobin with associated reticulocytopenia (i.e., transient aplastic crisis, TAC). TAC is usually self-limited and reticulocyte production recurs within a few days.

Patients with SCD who present with anemia, a decreased reticulocyte count, and fever, should be suspected of having parvovirus B19 infection, even in the absence of a rash. Parvovirus B19 may also lead to other complications in patients with sickle cell diseases, such as splenic sequestration crisis.

Key learning point: Parvovirus B19 infection can cause transient aplastic crisis in sickle cell disease, leading to acute severe anemia with reticulocytopenia and minimal compensatory bone marrow response.

E) INCORRECT:

Splenic sequestration crisis usually manifests with acute-onset severe anemia. However, unlike in this patient, anemia in splenic sequestration crisis is associated with an increased reticulocyte count. Additionally, patients characteristically have acute left upper quadrant pain (due to rapid enlargement of the spleen) and signs of intravascular volume depletion (e.g., severe hypotension) due to the trapping of blood in the spleen. Lastly, splenic sequestration crisis primarily affects infants and young children; older children and adults with SCD often have a nonfunctional, atrophic spleen because of years of damage from sickle cells, making this an unlikely diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient has sickle cell disease (SCD) and presents with severe symptomatic anemia (evident from his palpitations, shortness of breath, tachycardia, and ejection murmur) and a low reticulocyte count, which suggests impaired erythropoiesis due to an aplastic crisis.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man comes to your clinic for follow-up. He was diagnosed with latent tuberculosis infection 3 months ago and has been taking his medication consistently. For the past 6 weeks, he has experienced generalized fatigue and dyspnea on exertion. He does not smoke and drinks two to three beers on weekends. Vital signs are normal. On examination, he has conjunctival pallor. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood

78 g/L (125–170)


Mean corpuscular volume (MCV), blood

72 fL (80–100)


Red cell distribution width (RDW), blood
17% (11.5%–15.5%)


Reticulocyte percentage, blood
0.7% (0.5%–1.5%)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
6.8 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Platelet count, blood
175 × 109/L (130–380)


Creatinine, blood
71 μmol/L (49–93)


Iron, blood
44.1 μmol/L (12–31)


Ferritin, blood
446 μg/L (24–336)


Iron-binding capacity, total (TIBC), blood

38.0 μmol/L (45–81)


Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Beta thalassemia minor is a potential cause of microcytic anemia (MCV < 80 fL). However, patients with beta thalassemia minor are usually asymptomatic with a normal or elevated reticulocyte count and have otherwise normal labs. This patient who is fatigued and dyspneic likely has a different cause of anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

A pure red cell aplasia is an isolated decrease in red cell production, which often results from autoimmune disease, malignancy, drugs, or infection (e.g., with parvovirus B19). Lab findings would indicate severe normocytic anemia with virtually no reticulocytes, indicating absent erythropoiesis. This patient's MCV < 80 fL indicates microcytic anemia and his symptoms are better explained by another condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency is the most common type of anemia and the leading cause of microcytic anemia (MCV < 80 fL) with increased red cell distribution width. Laboratory studies in patients with iron deficiency would show decreased iron and ferritin, as well as increased total iron-binding capacity, unlike the results seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic inflammation (e.g., due to tuberculosis) can cause anemia of chronic disease. This patient is likely undergoing treatment for latent tuberculosis and, therefore, chronic inflammation is unlikely. Moreover, while anemia of chronic disease manifests with increased ferritin and decreased total iron-binding capacity, the serum iron would be decreased; iron is sequestered in storage sites and thus unavailable for heme synthesis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, low MCV, and decreased hemoglobin suggest microcytic anemia as the most likely cause of his symptoms. Increased iron and ferritin with decreased total iron-binding capacity are consistent with sideroblastic anemia, most likely due to isoniazid, the first-line treatment for latent tuberculosis. Isoniazid can result in vitamin B6 deficiency, which in turn impairs the function of ALA synthase, because this enzyme requires vitamin B6 as a cofactor for an important step of heme biosynthesis. Consequently, iron accumulates in the mitochondria and is unable to be used in heme synthesis. The elevated red cell distribution width reflects the increased variability of cell size seen in sideroblastic anemia. A bone marrow aspirate will show blue-ringed sideroblasts as the iron in the mitochondria of normoblasts absorbs Prussian blue stain.

To avoid adverse effects in patients receiving treatment with isoniazid, pyridoxine (vitamin B6 prophylaxis) should also be administered.

Key learning point: Isoniazid can cause sideroblastic anemia by inducing vitamin B6 deficiency, which impairs heme synthesis and leads to microcytic anemia with increased iron and ferritin levels.
questions.hint: A Prussian blue stain of the bone marrow aspirate in this patient would show blue-ringed sideroblasts.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl comes to your clinic with a 4-month history of fatigue. She had infectious mononucleosis 8 weeks ago. Her menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 days with moderate flow. On examination, she has pale conjunctivae and scaling at the corners of her mouth. The remainder of the examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood

103 g/L (115–155)


Red blood cell (RBC) count, blood
3.7 × 1012/L (3.50–5.00)


Mean corpuscular volume (MCV), blood

74 fL (80–100)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
6.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Platelet count, blood
280 × 109/L (130–380)


Reticulocyte percentage, blood
0.4% (0.5–1.5)


A peripheral blood smear shows erythrocytes of unequal sizes. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 is measured in order to diagnose vitamin B12 deficiency, which would cause anemia and occasionally, angular cheilitis. However, vitamin B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia rather than the microcytic anemia seen in this patient. Instead, the patient would have other features such as glossitis or neuropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobin electrophoresis is used to diagnose inherited hematologic disorders associated with abnormal hemoglobin production such as sickle cell disease and thalassemia. Although thalassemia is an important cause of microcytic anemia, patients with thalassemia typically have a Mentzer index < 13, a normal or high reticulocyte count, and, unless the patient has beta-thalassemia major, significant anisocytosis would not be expected. A different test would be more appropriate in the initial workup of microcytic anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

The direct Coombs test is used to diagnose autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA), which is associated with recent viral infection (e.g., infectious mononucleosis). However, hemolytic anemia most commonly presents with a normal or increased MCV and an increased reticulocyte count.

D) CORRECT:

Iron deficiency is the most common cause of microcytic anemia, especially in women due to blood loss during menstruation, which can gradually decrease the body's iron stores. Ferritin measurement is the first-line test for assessing the body's iron stores and screening for iron deficiency anemia (IDA). The changes associated with IDA include decreased ferritin, increased transferrin, and decreased transferrin saturation. Further work-up would be needed to ascertain whether abnormal bleeding or malabsorption may be causing the iron deficiency.

Key learning point: Serum ferritin is the most appropriate initial test to diagnose iron deficiency anemia, especially in cases of microcytic anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow biopsy is used to diagnose diseases such as aplastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndrome, and hematologic malignancies. It may also be used to directly measure bone marrow iron stores in patients with suspected iron deficiency anemia when first-line testing does not lead to a diagnosis. However, an invasive test such as bone marrow biopsy would not be indicated for initial work-up.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, pallor, angular cheilitis, decreased hemoglobin, decreased mean corpuscular volume, a Mentzer index > 13, and anisocytosis. These features are consistent with the most common form of anemia.

questions.text:
You are seeing a 10-month-old boy in your clinic for a well-child examination. His medical history is unremarkable. His maternal uncle has alpha thalassemia trait. He is exclusively breastfed. He is able to walk with one hand held, throw a small ball, and pick up objects between his thumb and index finger. He can say “mama” and “dada.” Physical examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood

100 g/L (115–155)


Mean corpuscular volume (MCV), blood

72 fL (80–100)


Red cell distribution width (RDW), blood

18% (11.5%–15.5%)


Reticulocyte percentage, blood
0.6% (0.5%–1.5%)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
7.2 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Platelet count, blood
280 × 109/L (130–380)


Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the hemoglobin alpha chain can cause alpha thalassemia trait, which can manifest with microcytic anemia. This patient's family history of alpha thalassemia trait increases the likelihood of him having this condition. However, patients with alpha thalassemia trait typically have a low or normal RDW. Patients who carry 3–4 defective alleles in the genes that encode the α-globin chain develop hemoglobin H disease, which manifests with jaundice and anemia at birth; this patient's medical history is unremarkable.

B) INCORRECT:

An increased HbS concentration is seen in patients with sickle cell disease, which can be asymptomatic during the first year of life, as the production of HbF decreases and HbS concentration increases. Patients typically have a high RDW and chronic hemolytic anemia, which is often normocytic rather than microcytic. In addition, patients have reticulocytosis because immature reticulocytes are released to help maintain oxygenation; this patient has a normal reticulocyte count.

C) CORRECT:

Insufficient iron intake can cause iron deficiency anemia (IDA), which typically manifests with microcytic anemia and an increased RDW with no compensatory increase in reticulocytes. While IDA is usually asymptomatic, severe cases can manifest with lethargy, pallor, and irritability. IDA is common in infants > 6 months of age who are exclusively breastfed, only fed cow's milk, or who were born prematurely. Because IDA can lead to neurocognitive deficits, iron supplementation is recommended for exclusively breastfed infants starting from the age of 4 months (or at the age of 2 weeks for premature infants) and until the intake of iron-rich food is sufficient. Treatment of IDA consists of oral iron supplementation and dietary changes.

Key learning point: Iron deficiency anemia in infants commonly results from insufficient dietary iron, especially in those exclusively breastfed beyond 6 months without iron supplementation or iron-rich foods.

D) INCORRECT:

Lead toxicity can rarely cause mild microcytic anemia. The most common manifestations of symptomatic lead toxicity are neurocognitive deficits. However, this patient is meeting developmental milestones for a 12-month-old infant. Moreover, he does not have clear risk factors for lead exposure (e.g., living in housing that was built before the 1970s).

E) INCORRECT:

Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by defective erythrocyte membrane proteins, which lead to premature destruction of erythrocytes, extravascular hemolysis, and hemolytic anemia. However, spherocytosis typically manifests with normocytic anemia and reticulocytosis. Patients may be asymptomatic or develop jaundice, splenomegaly, and/or black pigment gallstones.
questions.hint: This patient's laboratory studies show microcytic anemia and an increased red blood cell distribution width (RDW).

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis comes to your clinic for follow-up one week after being discharged from the hospital. During her hospitalization, she received acetaminophen and erythropoietin. Which one of the following additional conditions is she most likely to have?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency can impair the coagulation cascade, leading to pathological bleeding. Symptoms include ecchymosis, hematomas, and hemarthroses. Anemia might be seen, but it would not be due to reduced RBC production, so substitution of EPO would not be effective.

B) CORRECT:

Anemia of chronic disease (ACD) occurs in patients with a chronic disease process such as inflammation (e.g., this patient's rheumatoid arthritis), malignancy, infection, or renal failure. ACD is characterized by reduced erythropoietic response to both endogenous and exogenous EPO. However, high doses of EPO can overcome this hyporesponsiveness and are recommended in these patients.

Key learning point: Anemia of chronic disease is common in chronic inflammatory conditions and is characterized by reduced erythropoietin responsiveness, but may improve with high-dose erythropoietin therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is an acquired form of a low platelet count secondary to antibody formation against GpIIb/IIIa on platelets. ITP does not perturb the structure or function of WBCs, RBCs, or coagulation factors (i.e., isolated thrombocytopenia). It can be treated with thrombopoietin or thrombopoietin receptor agonists, but EPO would not be effective in treating thrombocytopenia.

D) INCORRECT:

Agranulocytosis is a condition characterized by severe leukopenia. Treatment may involve granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) but not EPO.

E) INCORRECT:

Factor VIII deficiency is seen in hemophilia A, a blood clotting disorder that leads to serious bleeding (e.g., hemarthrosis, muscular or soft tissue hematomas). Usually only males are affected, as it is primarily an X-linked recessive disease. Treatment includes desmopressin, or in severe cases, substitution of factor VIII. Substitution of EPO would not be effective.
questions.hint: Erythropoietin (EPO) stimulates erythroid cell division and proliferation and inhibits erythroid progenitor apoptosis.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to your clinic with worsening fatigue and an unintentional 6.8-kg weight loss over the past 2 months. She also reports a craving for soil and clay that has persisted for several months. Her medical history includes osteoarthritis of the knees, managed with acetaminophen. Her pulse is 116/min and blood pressure is 125/84 mm Hg. On examination, she has diffuse teeth abrasions and dirt in the sublingual folds. Further evaluation is most likely to show which one of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is observed in patients with hypothyroidism. Hypothyroidism often manifests with fatigue, weight gain, constipation, bradycardia, and cold intolerance. This patient's weight loss and pica are not consistent with hypothyroidism, which makes elevated TSH levels an unlikely additional finding.

B) INCORRECT:

A decreased CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is seen in patients with immunodeficiency. Unintentional weight loss and chronic fatigue can be signs of chronic conditions resulting in immunodeficiency (e.g., HIV infection). However, further symptoms, particularly an increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections, are expected in patients with a decreased CD4+ T-lymphocyte count. Moreover, immunodeficiency is not associated with pica, making this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

A positive Schilling test indicates vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to macrocytic anemia that manifests with fatigue and tachycardia. Important risk factors for the development of vitamin B12 deficiency include malnutrition (e.g., in veganism or restricted dietary intake due to anorexia nervosa), inflammatory bowel disease, and bariatric surgery. Patients with this condition may present with a variety of symptoms, including glossitis, neurological symptoms (e.g., diminished executive functioning and personality changes), and gait abnormalities (due to peripheral neuropathy or subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord), none of which are seen here. Furthermore, vitamin B12 deficiency is not typically associated with unintentional weight loss or pica.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum lead concentration is caused by the consumption of substances contaminated with lead (e.g., due to pica). Common sources include paint, particularly in older houses, and contaminated water. Lead poisoning typically causes anemia (due to increased free radical formation and ensuing hemolysis), which manifests with fatigue and tachycardia. However, this patient does not have other expected findings such as abdominal pain, headaches, irritability, reduced cognition, or gingival lead lines.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's fatigue, pica, and tachycardia indicate iron deficiency anemia (IDA). The combination of IDA and unintentional weight loss in a 63-year-old patient raises concern for chronic gastrointestinal bleeding from colorectal cancer (CRC). A stool guaiac test, which can detect the presence of occult blood in the stool, is likely to be positive. Following a stool guaiac test, this patient should undergo further diagnostic studies (e.g., colonoscopy and esophagogastroduodenoscopy) in order to confirm the underlying source of bleeding.

IDA from chronic occult blood loss in the absence of obstructive symptoms is especially common in patients with right-sided colon carcinoma. In contrast, left-sided colon carcinomas more commonly manifest with changes in bowel habits, blood-streaked stools, and colicky abdominal pain, while rectal carcinomas often manifest with diminished caliber of stools, tenesmus, and hematochezia.

Key learning point: Iron deficiency anemia presenting with pica in older adults often indicates chronic gastrointestinal blood loss, which can be detected by a positive stool guaiac test.
questions.hint: This patient's unusual appetite for soil and clay, resulting in teeth abrasions and dirt in the sublingual folds, should raise concern for pica, which may be associated with a particular micronutrient deficiency.

questions.text: You are seeing a 22-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, intermittent rigors, and night sweats. She also reports progressive fatigue over the past month. Five weeks ago, she was hospitalized in Guatemala and received intravenous antibiotics for bacterial meningitis. Her temperature is 39.4°C, pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. On examination, she has pallor, scattered petechiae, and ecchymoses. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin of 90 g/L (115–155), white blood cell count of 1.1 × 109/L (3.5–10.5) with 30% segmented neutrophils, and platelet count of 20 × 109/L (130–380). Which one of the following antibiotics was she most likely treated with?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Side effects of daptomycin include reversible myopathy, rhabdomyolysis, and allergic pneumonitis. However, it is not associated with pancytopenia. Moreover, daptomycin is not a recommended treatment for bacterial meningitis.

B) CORRECT:

Pancytopenia due to bone marrow suppression is a side effect of therapy with chloramphenicol. It may develop in a dose-dependent, reversible manner or manifest as dose-independent irreversible aplastic anemia with a sudden onset up to several months after treatment. Aplastic anemia is a rare but potentially fatal side effect, so the use of chloramphenicol has been limited in resource-rich countries. However, due to its low cost, it is often still used to treat bacterial meningitis caused by H. influenzae, N. meningitidis, or S. pneumoniae in resource-limited countries.

Key learning point: Chloramphenicol can cause dose-dependent reversible bone marrow suppression or rare, potentially fatal, dose-independent aplastic anemia, leading to pancytopenia as a serious side effect.

C) INCORRECT:

Linezolid may cause bone marrow suppression, especially thrombocytopenia. However, linezolid-induced bone marrow suppression is usually dose-dependent and occurs during therapy, not weeks later, as in this patient. Moreover, this antibiotic is not recommended as a first-line treatment for bacterial meningitis but is used as a reserve drug for the treatment of resistant gram-positive bacteria. It is therefore unlikely that this patient was treated with linezolid. Further side effects include peripheral neuropathy, gastrointestinal upset, and the risk of serotonin syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin in combination with a third-generation cephalosporin is a first-line treatment for bacterial meningitis in this patient's age group. However, this antibiotic is not associated with pancytopenia. Side effects of vancomycin include nephrotoxicity, anaphylactic reactions, and vancomycin flushing reaction.

E) INCORRECT:

Side effects of doxycycline include hepatotoxicity, discoloration of teeth, inhibition of bone growth in children, damage to mucous membranes (e.g., esophagitis), and photosensitivity. However, this antibiotic is not associated with pancytopenia. Although oral doxycycline is used for the treatment of Lyme meningitis in some countries, this patient received IV rather than oral antibiotics.
questions.hint: The patient's pancytopenia is likely caused by an antibiotic that can also cause gray baby syndrome in premature infants.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a 6-month history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with fatigue and dyspnea on exertion. She has no melena, hematochezia, or heavy menstrual bleeding. Physical examination shows pale conjunctiva and mild synovitis of the wrists. Laboratory results show hemoglobin 8.8 g/dL, hematocrit 26%, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 74 μm3, and normal platelet count. Iron studies show ferritin 180 ng/mL, serum iron 45 μ/dL, and total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) 280 μ/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Microcytic anemia with elevated ferritin and decreased TIBC are consistent with anemia of chronic disease secondary to rheumatoid arthritis. The chronic inflammatory state increases hepcidin production, leading to reduced iron availability despite adequate iron stores.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency typically manifests with macrocytic anemia (MCV > 100 μm3) and megaloblastic changes, including hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral blood smear. This patient has microcytic anemia, which is not a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Thalassemia trait usually manifests with normal iron study results and often an elevated reticulocyte count. The abnormal iron findings in this patient make an alternative diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency anemia typically manifests with decreased ferritin and increased TIBC. This patient has elevated ferritin and normal to low TIBC, making an alternative diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Sideroblastic anemia typically manifests with elevated ferritin, elevated serum iron, and increased transferrin saturation. This patient has low serum iron, making sideroblastic anemia unlikely.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with several months of fatigue and exertional dyspnea. She has conjunctival pallor and tachycardia. Laboratory studies reveal hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL, MCV 68 fL, RDW 18%, ferritin 10 ng/mL, and elevated total iron binding capacity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anemia of chronic disease typically presents with normal to elevated ferritin levels and normal RDW. The low ferritin and elevated RDW in this patient are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Thalassemia trait typically presents with normal to elevated ferritin levels and normal RDW. While it causes microcytic anemia, iron studies are usually normal.

C) INCORRECT:

Sideroblastic anemia is characterized by elevated ferritin and transferrin saturation levels.

D) INCORRECT:

While oral iron supplementation will be needed for treatment, the underlying cause of iron deficiency must be identified first. In women of reproductive age with severe iron deficiency anemia, gastrointestinal bleeding should be ruled out even when heavy menstrual bleeding is present.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – The combination of microcytic anemia with low ferritin, elevated RDW, and elevated total iron binding capacity is diagnostic of iron deficiency anemia. The clinical presentation of fatigue, dyspnea, and pallor supports this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with 4 weeks of worsening fatigue and dyspnea on exertion. Examination reveals pallor and mild tachycardia. Laboratory results show white blood cells and platelets within normal limits, hemoglobin 8.4 g/dL, MCV 102 fL, and reticulocyte count 1.8%. Peripheral blood smear shows hypersegmented neutrophils. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Vitamin B12 deficiency is a major cause of megaloblastic anemia, indicated by the combination of macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral blood smear.

B) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency anemia typically presents as microcytic anemia with decreased MCV. While it can initially manifest as normocytic anemia, this patient has macrocytic anemia with megaloblastic changes, which is inconsistent with iron deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Aplastic anemia typically causes normocytic anemia rather than macrocytic anemia. Additionally, aplastic anemia usually presents with pancytopenia affecting all cell lines rather than isolated anemia with megaloblastic changes.

D) INCORRECT:

Anemia of chronic disease typically presents as normocytic anemia in early stages and microcytic anemia in later stages. It does not produce megaloblastic changes with hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral blood smear.

E) INCORRECT:

Myelodysplastic syndrome can present with macrocytic anemia and would require bone marrow biopsy for diagnosis. However, the classic finding of hypersegmented neutrophils strongly suggests megaloblastic anemia rather than a primary bone marrow disorder.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with 3 weeks of progressive fatigue and easy bruising. She has been treated for a thyroid condition for several months. Physical examination reveals pallor and petechiae. Laboratory results show hemoglobin 7.2 g/dL, white blood cell count 1,800/mm3, and platelet count 45,000/mm3. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Discharge with iron supplementation and primary care follow-up
Obtain peripheral blood smear and reticulocyte count
Administer packed red blood cells and platelets
Start broad-spectrum antibiotics and admit to medicine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation would not address the underlying pancytopenia, and outpatient management is inappropriate given the severity of cytopenias and risk of bleeding and infection complications.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – The patient presents with pancytopenia (decreased red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets) in the setting of medication use for thyroid disease. This clinical picture is consistent with aplastic anemia, which can be caused by antithyroid medications. Urgent hematology consultation is essential for definitive diagnosis, bone marrow evaluation, and initiation of appropriate treatment including discontinuation of the offending agent.

C) INCORRECT:

While these tests may provide additional diagnostic information, they would delay definitive management. The CBC already demonstrates pancytopenia requiring immediate specialist evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Transfusion decisions should be made in coordination with hematology consultation. Prophylactic transfusions are not routinely recommended in stable patients with aplastic anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

While infection risk is elevated with neutropenia, there are no signs of active infection. The priority is addressing the underlying cause of the pancytopenia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of peptic ulcer disease presents with weakness and dizziness that began 6 hours ago. His wife reports he has been having dark, tarry stools for the past day. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae and dry mucous membranes. Vital signs are BP, 92/58; P, 118; R, 20; T, 36.8°C (98.2°F); SpO2, 97% on room air. Laboratory results show hemoglobin 6.2 g/dL and normal platelet count. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Initiate packed red blood cell transfusion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nasogastric tube lavage may help assess the severity of upper gastrointestinal bleeding but does not provide immediate hemodynamic benefit. Severe anemia and hemodynamic instability require urgent management and should not be delayed for diagnostic procedures.

B) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors are appropriate adjunctive therapy for suspected peptic ulcer bleeding. However, this patient has hemodynamic instability, which is life-threatening. Patients with acute hemorrhagic anemia and hemodynamic compromise require urgent resuscitation before acid suppression therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Endoscopy is important for source identification and therapeutic intervention in upper gastrointestinal bleeding but should not delay immediate resuscitation measures. Hemodynamic instability and severe anemia require urgent management before diagnostic or therapeutic procedures.

D) INCORRECT:

While crystalloid resuscitation may provide temporary hemodynamic support, this patient has acute blood loss anemia with hemoglobin of 6.2 g/dL and hemodynamic compromise. Crystalloids cannot restore oxygen-carrying capacity in patients with acute hemorrhagic anemia and hemodynamic instability.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has acute blood loss anemia with hemoglobin 6.2 g/dL and hemodynamic instability. Blood transfusion is the immediate priority in hemodynamically unstable patients with acute anemia.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of progressive fatigue and dyspnea on exertion. She has a 15-year history of rheumatoid arthritis, for which she takes methotrexate and occasional nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. On examination, she has pale conjunctivae and bilateral swelling and tenderness of the metacarpophalangeal joints. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 9.8 g/dL, a hematocrit of 30%, and a mean corpuscular volume of 88 fL. Iron studies are ordered to further evaluate her anemia. Which of the following findings is most likely?

choices.text: Decreased serum iron, decreased total iron-binding capacity, and increased ferritin
Increased serum iron, increased total iron-binding capacity, and decreased ferritin
Normal serum iron, normal total iron-binding capacity, and normal ferritin
Increased serum iron, decreased total iron-binding capacity, and increased ferritin
Decreased serum iron, increased total iron-binding capacity, and decreased ferritin

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Decreased serum iron, decreased total iron-binding capacity, and increased ferritin are typical findings in anemia of chronic disease, in which inflammatory cytokines (e.g., interleukin-6) stimulate the liver to produce hepcidin. Hepcidin blocks iron absorption from the gut and traps iron within macrophages of the reticuloendothelial system. This leads to low serum iron available for erythropoiesis. The liver also decreases the production of transferrin, the main iron transport protein, resulting in a low total iron-binding capacity. Because total body iron stores are adequate or increased (just sequestered) and ferritin is an acute phase reactant, its level is normal or elevated.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased serum iron, increased total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), and decreased ferritin do not represent a classic pattern of findings for any common type of anemia. An increased serum iron level with an increased TIBC is physiologically inconsistent because transferrin production, which is reflected by the TIBC, is typically downregulated when iron levels are high.

C) INCORRECT:

Normal iron studies would suggest that this patient's normocytic anemia is not related to iron metabolism. This might be seen in conditions such as anemia of chronic kidney disease or aplastic anemia. However, given the significant chronic inflammatory state from active rheumatoid arthritis, it is highly probable that iron regulation would be affected.

D) INCORRECT:

This pattern suggests an iron overload state, such as hemochromatosis or ineffective erythropoiesis, as seen in sideroblastic anemia. In these conditions, iron is absorbed but cannot be properly utilized or stored, leading to high circulating iron levels. This patient's clinical presentation is driven by chronic inflammation, not a primary disorder of iron metabolism or overload.

E) INCORRECT:

This pattern is characteristic of iron deficiency anemia (IDA). Although this diagnosis is plausible due to potential gastrointestinal bleeding from nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug use, this patient's active, long-standing rheumatoid arthritis makes anemia of chronic disease more likely. In IDA, total body iron stores are depleted, leading to low ferritin. The liver compensates by increasing transferrin production to maximize iron absorption, resulting in an elevated total iron-binding capacity.
questions.hint: This patient's long-standing rheumatoid arthritis and normocytic anemia are characteristic of anemia of chronic disease, also known as anemia of inflammation.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He was diagnosed with latent tuberculosis infection 3 months ago and has been taking his medication consistently. He has had generalized fatigue and dyspnea on exertion for the past 6 weeks. He does not smoke and drinks two to three beers on weekends. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
7.8 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
72 μm3


Red cell distribution width
17% (N = 13–15)


Reticulocyte count
0.7%


Leukocyte count
6800/mm3



Platelet count
175,000/mm3



Serum



 Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL


 Iron
246 μg/dL


 Ferritin
446 ng/mL


 Total iron-binding capacity

212 μg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency is the most common type of anemia and the leading cause of microcytic anemia (MCV < 80 μm3) with increased red cell distribution width. Laboratory studies in patients with iron deficiency would show decreased iron and ferritin, as well as increased total iron-binding capacity, unlike the results seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

A pure red cell aplasia is an isolated decrease in red cell production, which often results from autoimmune disease, malignancy, drugs, or infection (e.g., with parvovirus B19). Lab findings would indicate severe normocytic anemia with virtually no reticulocytes, indicating absent erythropoiesis. This patient's MCV < 80 μm3 indicates microcytic anemia and his symptoms are better explained by another condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic inflammation (e.g., due to tuberculosis) can cause anemia of chronic disease. This patient is likely undergoing treatment for latent tuberculosis and, therefore, chronic inflammation is unlikely. Moreover, while anemia of chronic disease manifests with increased ferritin and decreased total iron-binding capacity, the serum iron would be decreased; iron is sequestered in storage sites and thus unavailable for heme synthesis.

D) INCORRECT:

Beta thalassemia minor is a potential cause of microcytic anemia (MCV < 80 μm3). However, patients with beta thalassemia minor are usually asymptomatic with a normal or elevated reticulocyte count and have otherwise normal labs. This patient who is fatigued and dyspneic likely has a different cause of anemia.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, low MCV, and decreased hemoglobin suggest microcytic anemia as the most likely cause of his symptoms. Increased iron and ferritin with decreased total iron-binding capacity are consistent with sideroblastic anemia, most likely due to isoniazid, the first-line treatment for latent tuberculosis. Isoniazid can result in vitamin B6 deficiency, which in turn impairs the function of ALA synthase, because this enzyme requires vitamin B6 as a cofactor for an important step of heme biosynthesis. Consequently, iron accumulates in the mitochondria and is unable to be used in heme synthesis. The elevated red cell distribution width reflects the increased variability of cell size seen in sideroblastic anemia. A bone marrow aspirate will show blue-ringed sideroblasts as the iron in the mitochondria of normoblasts absorbs Prussian blue stain.

To avoid adverse effects in patients receiving treatment with isoniazid, pyridoxine (vitamin B6 prophylaxis) should also be administered.

F) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency is a common cause of macrocytic anemia (MCV > 100 μm3). This patient has an MCV < 80 μm3, which means his symptoms are instead due to microcytic anemia.
questions.hint: A Prussian blue stain of the bone marrow aspirate in this patient would show blue-ringed sideroblasts.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of right-sided shoulder pain for 1 day. He has not had chills or sweating. At the age of 3 and 4, he was treated twice in the emergency department for painful swelling of his hands and feet. He emigrated with his family from Kenya 2 years ago. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 123/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no tenderness, erythema, or joint swelling of the shoulder. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
7 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
88 μm


Reticulocyte count
9%


Leukocyte count
12,000/mm3



A peripheral blood smear is most likely to show which of the following abnormalities?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ring-shaped inclusions are characteristically seen in erythrocytes infected with plasmodium. These inclusions represent immature trophozoites. Malaria, which is endemic in Kenya, is caused by infection with the plasmodium species and manifests with joint pain and anemia, as seen here. Additional symptoms include high-grade fever with periodic spikes as well as flu-like symptoms, none of which are seen here. Also, the typical incubation period is 7–42 days; this patient emigrated to the US 2 years ago, making malaria an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Compared to other forms of malaria, trophozoites of falciparum malaria are characterized by smaller and finer ring-shaped inclusions (green overlay). Plasmodium falciparum invades many erythrocytes, and one erythrocyte is typically invaded by more than one plasmodium, which is not the case in other forms of malaria.

B) INCORRECT:

Teardrop-shaped erythrocytes (i.e., dacrocytes) are associated with extramedullary hematopoiesis (e.g., from myelofibrosis, thalassemia, splenomegaly). Although these conditions may cause anemia, they are not associated with recurrent pain crises.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Erythrocytes with a teardrop shape can be seen throughout the image (red overlay). The majority of the erythrocytes appear round and normal.

Teardrop-shaped erythrocytes, known as dacrocytes, are found in conditions that involve extramedullary hematopoiesis (e.g., myelofibrosis, thalassemia, splenomegaly).

C) CORRECT:

Nuclear remnants in erythrocytes (i.e., Howell-Jolly bodies, HJBs) appear as small basophilic spots in the periphery of circulating red blood cells. Normally, HJBs are removed by the spleen. Patients with sickle cell disease typically develop functional asplenia by 4 years of age due to repeated infarction secondary to vaso-occlusion (autosplenectomy). Therefore, HJBs are likely to be seen on this patient's peripheral blood smear.

Other hematologic abnormalities found in patients who have undergone (auto)splenectomy include target cells, neutrophilia, decreased production of immunoglobulins, and reactive thrombocytosis.
Image Description:

Peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain)

Numerous erythrocytes (light pink disc-like structures with central pallor) can be seen throughout the image. Howell-Jolly bodies are visible as small circular basophilic inclusions in the cytoplasm of the three erythrocytes (red overlay). A neutrophil with a polysegmented basophilic nucleus (in the center) and a lymphocyte with a large central round nucleus and a rim of basophilic cytoplasm (on the right side) are also visible.

Howell-Jolly bodies are usually removed by the spleen. They are typically seen in asplenic patients but can also appear in individuals with myelodysplastic syndromes or megaloblastic anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Fragmentation of erythrocytes leads to the development of schistocytes. Schistocytes are found on the peripheral blood smears of patients with microangiopathic hemolytic anemias (MAHAs), including hemolytic uremic syndrome, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. Although these conditions also manifest with anemia with high reticulocyte count, other features such as thrombocytopenia, a history of gastrointestinal infection, impaired kidney function, or neurological deficits would be expected. Furthermore, MAHAs are not associated with recurrent pain crises.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; high magnification)

Normal erythrocytes (example indicated by arrow; bottom left) and several fragmented erythrocytes (schistocytes; examples indicated by black dashed circles) with a normal convex side (example marked with red line) and a fragmented side that is concave or straight (example marked with blue line) can be seen. Additionally, multiple erythrocytes with dark staining Howell-Jolly bodies (examples indicated by arrowheads) are present.

Schistocytes are a diagnostic finding in microangiopathic hemolytic anemias. These cellular fragments can also result from mechanical damage to erythrocytes (e.g., due to prosthetic heart valves). Howell-Jolly bodies can occur in functional asplenia or after splenectomy, severe anemia, and bone marrow disorders (e.g., myelodysplastic syndrome).

E) INCORRECT:

Erythrocytes with no central pallor (i.e., spherocytes) are present in various conditions, including hereditary spherocytosis and autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Although these conditions also manifest with anemia with high reticulocyte count, they are not associated with recurrent pain crises.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Multiple spherocytes can be seen (red circles), which have a typical round (rather than biconcave) shape and no central pallor. The erythrocytes vary significantly in size, which is consistent with anisocytosis (red arrows). On electron microscopy (overlay box with drawings based on EM appearance), the spherical shape of spherocytes (1) and normal biconcave erythrocytes (2) can be seen.
questions.hint: This patient's ethnicity, history of hospitalizations due to bone pain, and anemia with high reticulocyte count indicate sickle cell disease.
